name: Handigaun
history: Hadigaun, one of the oldest and most historically significant settlements in the Kathmandu Valley, was once the heart of Nepal's Licchavi civilization, serving as the ancient capital and a thriving center of culture, religion, and politics. Its temples, stone spouts, and inscriptions bear testimony to its royal legacy and spiritual prominence. However, with the rise of modern urbanization and neglect of its heritage, Hadigaun has gradually lost its central role and much of its historical grandeur. Despite this, studying Handigaun is crucial, as it holds untapped insights into Nepal’s ancient urbanization, religious syncretism, and architectural innovations, serving as a key to understanding the nation’s rich cultural and historical identity.

monuments.name: Bhat Bhateni Temple
monuments.history:
The BhatBhateni Temple, located northwest of Hadigaun, is dedicated to the deities Bhat, Bhateni, and their child, Nanda/Bal Gopal. The temple is unique in that the deities are suspended on the wall instead of being placed on the ground, a distinctive feature (Acharya, 2021). The deities are also known by local names such as Brahmayani, "ह्मोपता द्यो/Mhopata Dhyo," "मे मैचाद्यो/Me MaichaDhyo," and "मोपतादेवी/Mopata Devi," and are believed to have the power to heal children's ailments. The temple's origins may date back to the Lichhavi period, with some believing it is linked to the Toran Ajima/Tudal Devi Temple, which contains an inscription from 475 A.D during King Manadeva's reign (Dikshita, 2059).
A prominent legend tells the story of a devout Brahmin couple, Sudev and Sudevi, from Bishalnagar (the ancient name for Hadigaun). The couple, known for their unwavering devotion to Lord Vishnu, were blessed with spiritual knowledge and earned the names "Bhat" and "Bhateni." They prayed for a child with all the good qualities of Vishnu. As they were too old to bear children at the time, Lord Vishnu promised them a child in the next life. Reborn into poverty, the couple continued their devotion to Vishnu and were blessed with a son who embodied all the attributes of Vishnu.
One day, an old Brahmin named Suddadev visited their home, and knowing of their exemplary character, he left behind a walking stick containing gold and set off on a 12-year pilgrimage. The couple, unaware of the gold inside, noticed the stick beginning to rot and discovered the gold. Struggling financially, they sold it, believing that Suddadev would not survive his pilgrimage. However, upon his return, Suddadev discovered the deceit. After initially being lied to by the couple, he saw a Garuda circling above, and it became clear to him that his stick had been sold. He cursed the couple, declaring, “Liars like you should not find land on this earth to set foot on. If my stick could be eaten away by moths, then surely that eagle above can swoop down and carry away your child.” At that moment, the Garuda swooped down and carried away the baby. The couple, having accumulated religious merit, found the strength to rise into the air to retrieve their son. To their surprise, their child revealed his true form—he was Vishnu-Narayan riding the Garuda. Vishnu, pleased by their devotion, blessed them, saying, “You shall remain in the sky as gods as you have remained loyal to me.” This legend explains why the images of Bhat and Bhateni are suspended in the temple (Acharya, 2021).
Another legend involves a farmer couple devoted to Vishnu, who prayed for the deity to be born as their child. Vishnu granted their wish, and in the next life, they were blessed with a child. One day, while the child was basking in the sun after being oiled, Garuda swooped down and took the child. The parents, chasing after the eagle, witnessed their son transform into Vishnu on Garuda's back. Vishnu, moved by their unwavering devotion, blessed them, allowing them to remain in the sky as gods.
The BhatBhateni Temple is a two-tiered structure with a copper roof and a golden pinnacle. The outer walls of the temple are adorned with carvings of the Astamatrikas, Ganesha, and other figures from the Malla period. The deities inside the temple face west and are suspended in the air to avoid startling visitors with their large images upon entry .(Karmacharya, P. (2024, November 8). Insights on Bhatbhateni Temple [Interview with Priest of the temple].) The temple is maintained by the Karmacharya clan, who perform daily rituals and uphold the temple's vibrant religious significance (Acharya, 2021).
The temple plays a central role in Hadigaun's cultural practices, particularly for parents praying for the health of their children. The annual jatra begins on Chaitra Sukla Chaturdasi (mid-April), with the deities temporarily housed at the Toran Ajima Temple. They are returned after a Hom Puja on Chaitra Sukla Purnima (late April). The temple sees increased visits on Saturdays, Tuesdays, and Thursdays, when locals come to offer prayers and seek blessings.’

monuments.name: Bhindyo Temple
monuments.history:
The Bhindyo Temple, also known as the Bhimsen Temple, is located in the northwestern corner of Hadigaun. This two-tiered structure is dedicated to Lord Bhimsen, with an image of the deity dating back to medieval times. The temple marks a significant entrance point to Hadigaun from the northwest, possibly serving as a historical access point to the city.
The temple is renowned for hosting the annual Bhimsen Jatra, which occurs alongside the Toran Ajima/Tudal Devi Jatra. These events are major cultural highlights for the community. The temple is currently cared for by the Dangol family, particularly SubhaNarayan Dangol, a local resident. A replica of the enshrined image is kept at the Dangol household and displayed during the Toran Ajima Jatra and Holi Purnima. The temple also hosts several important religious activities, including the Hom Puja during Si Punhi/Purnima (Magh full moon), Bhin Dwadasi (when food offerings are made to the deity), and Holi Purnima. (Dangol, S. N. (2024, November 14). Insights on Bhindyo Temple [Interview with Ritual Custodian of the temple].)
Historically, a Falcha (resting platform) once stood on the eastern side of the temple, but it was replaced by a club building (Tiwari, 2002). To the south of the temple is a Shakti Pith, housing images of deities such as Sankata, Mahankal, and Surya Narayan, as well as an upright stone symbolizing Lord Bhairav. Among these, a headless torso of Lord Shiva holding a Kamandalu is believed to date back to the early Licchavi period. To the southeast of the temple lies a Shivalinga, associated with a legendary fire that once devastated much of Hadigaun.
To the west of the temple, there was once a water well, and according to local lore, the Dhanamati river once flowed through this area. (Dangol, S. N. (2024, November 14). Insights on Bhindyo Temple [Interview with Ritual Custodian of the temple].) In recent years, additional structures have been added to the area, including a small Lord Ganesha temple to the south and a temple dedicated to Dakshinkali Bhagwati to the north, further enriching the region’s religious and cultural landscape.

monuments.name: Dhana Gamesh Temple
monuments.history:
The Dhana Ganesha Temple, located in the northern part of Hadigaun, is a historic two-story structure dedicated to the worship of significant deities. The eastern shrine enshrines the primary deity, Dhana Ganesha, while the identity of the deity in the western shrine remains a subject of debate.
The temple is believed to date back to the Licchavi period. The statue of Dhana Ganesha in the eastern shrine is notably fragmented; its left hand was once holding sweetmeats (laddu), while the object in its right hand remains uncertain. The statue in the western shrine is also contested, with some suggesting that it represents Bhairava, and others believing it depicts another form of Ganesha. Given the presence of a Bhairava image on the Toran (archway) above, it is likely that the statue in the western shrine represents Bhairava.
Dhana Ganesha, also known as Rog Vinayak, is revered for its healing powers, particularly in treating ailments. The second shrine is often referred to as Rog Vinayak, though this connection is still under research. The temple houses several ancient relics, including a 5th-century Hayagriva statue, a 2nd-century Mahisasurmardini, and an unidentified deity. The Hayagriva statue, revered by farmers as Balarāma, is the oldest of its kind in Nepal (Bangdel, 1982). Many of these statues were damaged during an Islamic invasion.
A local legend connects the Dhana Ganesha Temple to Chandra Vinayak in Chabahil. According to the myth, the original Chandra Vinayak statue, once enshrined in the Dhana Ganesha Temple, was stolen and dragged to Chabahil, earning it the name "Lhwasaala Ganedyo" (the dragged stone Ganesha). In response, the people of Hadigaun created a replacement statue, which is now worshipped as Dhana Ganesha. This myth links the two deities, and both statues are part of an annual procession that occurs on the day following the full moon of Kartik.(Prajapati, S. L. (2024, November 8). Insights on Dhana Ganesha Temple [Interview with President of the Conservation and Reformation Committee].)
The temple underwent renovations in 2003 A.D (BS 2060), which included the installation of a copper roof, a new finial, a bell, and marble flooring (Tiwari, 2002). Historically, the temple was managed by a Karmacharya priest, but currently, a Maharjan caretaker (dyahpahlah) from the local community performs the rituals. The temple holds significant cultural importance for the people of Hadigaun, who worship there during community festivals, personal rituals such as Pashni (the first rice feeding ceremony for a child), and on every Tuesday, when a replica of the Ganesha statue is brought out for worship.
The temple premises originally occupied 5 Ropani and 4 Aana of land. However, by 2045 B.S., the area was reduced to 3 Ropani and 7 Aana (Prajapati, K. L. (2024, November 8). Insights on Dhana Ganesha Temple [Interview with V- President of the Conservation and Reformation Committee].)). Despite these changes, the temple remains a central cultural and religious landmark in Hadigaun.

monuments.name: Nyara Hiti, Hadigaun Shiva Temple and Jogi Kuti
monuments.history:
Located on the eastern side of the Dhana Ganesha Temple is a stone water complex, housing five stone water spouts (hiti) of varying sizes. This hiti, known as Nyara Hiti or Pancha Dhara, is believed to have been constructed by Dhir Shamsher and Bir Shamsher and later renovated in 1970 B.S. (Acharya, 2021). Nyara Hiti holds religious and cultural significance in Hadigaun, particularly during the Gaijatra festival. It is believed that the hiti was created to provide water for Dhana Ganesha Temple, enabling devotees to take a holy bath before worship.
Adjacent to Nyara Hiti is the Gumbaj-style Shiva Temple, adding to the sacred atmosphere of the area. Within the same complex is the Jogi Kuti, a residential space built for the Naatha community yogis during the reign of Rana Bahadur Shah (Acharya, 2021).

monuments.name: Marpa Hiti
monuments.history:
Among the various hiti (stone water spouts) in Hadigaun, the Marpa Hiti is located on the northern slope of the Bhuteshwor Bhairav premises. Dating back to the 16th century, it was constructed by Shingh Prajapati (Acharya, 2021). While the physical structure of the hiti remains in good condition, the flow of water has unfortunately ceased following a haphazard reconstruction. The area surrounding the hiti, which was once a pond, has now been transformed into a park.( Magar, G. T. (2024, November 5). Insights on Marpa Hiti [Interview with Local Resident].)
Further investigation is needed to uncover more information about the hiti and its significance within the historical and cultural context of the area.

monuments.name: Krishna Mandir
monuments.history:
The Krishna Temple, located in Thatu Tole to the north of Hadigaun, is dedicated to Lord Krishna and is surrounded by a Pipal tree. The temple enshrines images of Krishna, Rukmini, and Satyabhama, believed to date back to the 17th-18th centuries (Acharya, 2021).
A noteworthy feature within the temple complex is the stone base of an older structure located in the northwest corner. This base is believed to belong to a Licchavi-era temple that originally housed a 2nd-century image of Goddess Lakshmi. The ancient Lakshmi statue is now displayed at the National Art Museum in Chhauni (Tiwari, 2002).

monuments.name: Bhuteshwor Bhairav
monuments.history:
Bhuteshwor Bhairava, located in Thatu Tole, is a central deity in Hadigaun, revered as the protector of the settlement. Locals regard him as the tutelary god of Hadigaun, and he plays an essential role in many significant community rituals. His gaze is perpetually directed southward, symbolizing his guardianship over the settlement.
The name "Bhuteshwor Bhairava" is derived from the nearby Shivalinga, known as Bhuteshwor Mahadeva. This Shivalinga is one of the prominent Piths among the 16,000 Piths of Sati Devi, the first wife of Mahadev. The area surrounding Bhuteshwor Bhairava includes several historical monuments from different periods. These include the Swasthani Yantra, over which Bhuteshwor Bhairava is considered the protector, a Dabali, Krishna Mandir, a newly added Chaitya, and temples dedicated to Narayana. The Narayana temples were relocated from the west during a road expansion. Before their relocation, one temple was built in a shikhar style, and the other in a tiered style. According to the ward member, the original Bhuteshwor Bhairava shrine was situated a few feet below ground and lacked the structural features seen today.(Karmacharya, B. P. (2024, November 14). Insights on Tudal Devi Dyochhen [Interview with Ward Member, Ward No 5])
Situated at the highest point in Hadigaun, Bhuteshwor Bhairava holds not only spiritual significance but also represents protection for the community. His location enhances his prominence, reinforcing his role as a guardian deity. His involvement in local rituals underscores his importance in safeguarding both the physical and spiritual well-being of the settlement (Tiwari, 2002).

monuments.name: Yoshin
monuments.history:
Yoshin refers to tall timber poles, about six stories high, cut from a single tree, and are integral to the Toran Ajima/Tudal Devi Jatra in Hadigaun. Two Yoshins are raised annually—one at Dabali and the other at Bhuteshwor. The festival begins on Chaitra Sukla Astami and ends on Baisakh Krishna Navami with the lowering of the poles (Tiwari, 2023).
The Yoshin raised at Bhuteshwor includes a halipata, a Kirat totem representing nagas, symbolizing Bhuteshwor Bhairav. The Yoshin at Dabali, though similar, lacks the halipata. The pole raising marks the Kirat New Year and honors both the king and the tutelary goddess at different locations (Tiwari, 2023).
The Yoshins are also seen as an invitation to celestial beings for the Tudal Devi Jatra, and the community observes several restrictions, including not sleeping outside the town, refraining from wearing imported shoes, and prohibiting loan repayments after the raising of Yoshins. These rules are communicated by the Shahi community through the Nyakhing, a special musical instrument (Prajapati, T. (2024, November 15). Insights on Yoshin [Interview with Member, Yoshin Guthi].).

monuments.name: Jarun Hiti (Jaladroni)
monuments.history:
Newar settlements, including Hadigaun, are renowned for their rich architecture, culture, and traditions, and one prominent feature is the Jarun Hiti, or Jaladroni—a stone water tank that reflects the daily life and practices of the community. While Newar settlements typically feature a Jaladroni, each one varies in size, shape, and design.
In Hadigaun, the Jarun Hiti is located on the road south of the Bhuteshwor Bhairava Temple, leading towards Dabali. This is the only remaining Jarun in the settlement, although there may have been others in the past that were destroyed over time. Although this Jarun is no longer used for its original purpose of providing water, it still serves a significant cultural function. It undergoes a ritual known as Kwo Puja during Paha Chahare, which symbolically marks the beginning of the upcoming Jatra. During this ritual, the Jarun is cleaned, worshiped, and a small amount of water is filled, serving as a reminder of the past when water was provided for those attending the Jatra. This ritual is believed to symbolize the historical role of the Jarun in serving the community. The responsibility for performing this act lies with a special Guthi, the Munche Guthi (Dangol, G. (2024, November 12). Insights on Jarun Hiti [Interview with Member, Munche Guthi].).
Further investigation is needed to uncover more details about this monument's historical and cultural significance

monuments.name: Toran Ajima Dyochhen
monuments.history:
Toran Ajima/Tudal Devi, also known as Vaishnavi Devi, is a revered Mother Goddess in Hadigaun, considered the protector of Vishalnagar. The Toran Ajima/Tudal Devi Temple, believed to date to the 5th century AD, is located in Bishalnagar-Chandol, northeast of Hadigaun, while her Dyochhen is situated in Dathu Tole within Hadigaun.
The Dyochhen, originally a one-story structure, was expanded into a three-story Newar-style building by five brothers from the Prajapati community. It becomes a central hub during the Toran Ajima/Tudal Devi Jatra, also called the Tisa Maligu Jatra (Acharya, 2021).
The Dyochhen’s location reflects its central role in Hadigaun, though it is mostly inactive except during the festival. Tiwari (2002) suggests the temple’s relocation to Bishalnagar may have been part of Lichchhavi-era efforts to shift deities and strengthen Vishnu dominance. Despite the relocation, Toran Ajima is brought back for the Jatra, maintaining her connection to Hadigaun.

monuments.name: Hadigaun Dabali Premises
monuments.history:
Hadigaun hosts five Dabalis, key open stages for cultural and religious events. The most significant is the Central Dabali, believed to be the site of Amshuvarma's Lichhavi-era coronation, making it one of the oldest Dabalis in the Kathmandu Valley (Acharya, 2021).
The Central Dabali contains two 7th-century stone inscriptions by Amshuvarma, detailing grants to key temples like Pashupatinath and Changunarayan, reflecting religious tolerance (Bajracharya, 1995; Tiwari, 2023). The northeastern corner is used for raising Yoshin, adding to its cultural importance.
Originally surrounded by Falchas with religious significance, only the northeastern (JalaFala) and northwestern (Ja Pha) Falchas remain. The southern Falcha was removed during road expansions, and the northern one, that serves as rest house for holy dancers/Gathus of Pachali Bhairab Dance, Navadurga Dance, no longer exists. (Karmacharya, B. P. (2024, November 14). Insights on Tudal Devi Dyochhen [Interview with Ward Member, Ward No 5].)
The Central Dabali hosts local festivals, including the Chokhate Narayan Jatra. Notably, the Pachali Bhairav Dance, performed every twelve years, continues to be a vital cultural tradition.

monuments.name: Bharavi Hiti
monuments.history:
The stone water spout, located down the wide-stepped path to the east of the Hadigaun Dabali, is one of the few intact Dhunge dharas from the Licchavi period and is considered one of the most important Dhunge dharas in the ancient city. According to the inscription, it was built by Bharavi, the grandson of Mandeva (who was the son of his daughter Vijayavati), in 550 AD. This complex contains three hiti, with two facing east and one facing south (Acharya, 2021).
The stone water spout, originating from the Licchavi period, channels water from Gahana Pokhari, which is situated at a higher elevation on the western side of Hadigaun, and drains into the Dhobi Khola river (Tiwari, 2002). This hiti may be religiously and culturally linked to the nearby Satyanarayan Temple, indicating that further research is needed to explore these.

monuments.name: Satya Narayan Temple Premises
monuments.history:
The Satyanarayan Temple, located east of Hadigaun Dabali near the Rudramati River, is a gumbaj-style temple housing a four-armed image of Lord Narayan, believed to date back to the 2nd or 3rd century A.D. The temple features sculptures and a nearby Shiva temple, with a 7th-century Garuda Stamba (column) inscribed to Dvaipayana Vyasa, erected by Anuparama Gupta.
The temple’s architecture suggests it originated during the Licchavi period, with scholars dating it to the 2nd-4th centuries A.D. It houses significant sculptures, including a Kubera statue (4th century A.D) and a Cāmuṇḍā statue (6th-7th centuries A.D ). A 1545 A.D inscription mentions the installation of an Umamaheswara statue by local figures during King Narendra Malla's reign.
Excavations between 1948 and 1988 revealed brick structures from the 2nd century A.D, highlighting Hadigaun’s ancient urban significance. A 2021 GPR survey uncovered older stone and brick structures beneath the temple. Additionally, a 750 A.D inscription on a jaḥdhuṃ water tank links the area to its ancient name, Andigrāma.
The temple remains a key religious center, with daily rituals performed by a member of the local Shrestha caste. It also plays a central role in preserving local cultural heritage and welcoming pilgrims who come to honor Lord Narayan.

monuments.name: The Mother goddesses and Char Narayan Temple
monuments.history:
The larger boundary of Hadigaun is ritually defined by the positions of nine power places, or pith, where the Rudra-Shaktis are believed to reside. These sites, known as pingam-dyo, form the outermost ring of protection for the area. One such site, located along the roadway to Hadigaun and Maligaun, hosts the ancient images of the Sapta Matrika Goddess and a small temple dedicated to Chaturmurti Char Narayan (Tiwari, 2002).
Within this periphery is an inscription by Bishnugupta of Mandeva Sambat 57, which outlines social provisions such as widow marriage and remarriage. This inscription is currently housed in the National Museum (Acharya, 2021). The site appears to have been an important pilgrimage destination in ancient times; however, it has lost much of its significance in the present day. Further investigation may be necessary to uncover its full historical and cultural significance.

monuments.name: Nasahdya
monuments.history:
Hadigaun is home to two image-less temples dedicated to Nasa Dyo (or Nateshwor), revered by the Newar community, especially in relation to performing arts like music and dance. The temples are located in Thathu Tole (north) and Kotaltole (south).

Thathu Tole Temple:
This temple is exclusively honored by the Pyeta Khala community, descendants of the original Maharjan people. They play Pyeta Baja that includes key musical instruments (Dhimay, Bhuchya, Kyepi, Ponga) during major festivals and rituals in Hadigaun. The temple was renovated following the 1990 B.S. and 2072 B.S. earthquakes (Maharjan, N. (2024, November 10). Insights on Nasa Dyo [Interview with Guru, Pyeta Khala].). Exclusive rituals are performed by the Pyeta Khala as part of their cultural tradition.
Kotaltole Temple:
Respected by the broader community, this temple is near a Dabali, indicating Hadigaun's historical role as a hub for dance and music. It was the birthplace of cultural practices like the Naugada Devi Dance and the 12 Barsey Dance, which remain integral to the religious traditions of the Kathmandu Valley (Acharya, 2021).

monuments.name: Bhima Nani
monuments.history:
Bhima Nani, also known as Shiva Nani, once housed a grand temple dedicated to Mahadev, located to the east of the Kartikya Temple. Today, only the sanctum floor remains, and the Shivalinga, named Bhimeshwor Mahadev, lies fragmented. A Lichhavi inscription reveals that Bhaumagupta, a powerful regent, usurped land grants that had been donated for the temple’s upkeep (Tiwari, 2002).
Inscriptions suggest that the site remained active until at least 818 AD, when Bhagyachandra installed a deity image there (Bajracharya, 2025 BS). However, the inscribed stone from the late Lichhavi period is now lost (Tiwari, 2002). Historically, Bhima Nani was part of a renowned Kirat-era temple complex called Bhuvaneswor Devkul. This temple and its surrounding area were culturally significant, with a rare stepped well located to the west, now within a private garden. The well, believed to carry holy water and guarded by the naga (serpent deity), plays an important role in the Chokhate Narayan Jatra. It may have also been part of Hadigaun’s Lichchhavi-era water supply system.
Efforts by King Narendradev to restore Bhuvaneswor Devkul after the disturbances and the fire of the late 7th century were unsuccessful, and the site eventually faded into obscurity. Interestingly, the Shivalinga’s Jalhari (water basin) faces the Ishan Kon (northeast), unlike most Shivalingas, which face north. The presence of another water well to the south, near the residence of the Mahantas, further suggests the site’s religious, cultural, and political significance in its prime (Acharya, S. (2024, November 12). Insights on Bhimanani [Interview with Local Resident].).

monuments.name: Kumar Temple
monuments.history:
Located in Kotal Tole, Hadigaun, Kathmandu, the temple features a two-tiered copper roof, roof struts adorned with erotic carvings, and a main entrance highlighted by a new wooden archway depicting Kumar Kartikya. The sanctum houses a late 8th-century statue of Kumar Kartikya on a peacock, and while the temple is locally revered as "Garudbahini Bhagwati," its iconography identifies it as Kumar. The complex also includes a 16th-century Umamaheswara statue. Although the exact date of the temple's construction remains unclear, the style of the Kumar statue suggests an 8th-century origin, with some sources proposing the 13th century. Nearby inscriptions from 1700 AD and 1701 AD document offerings to Kumar and past renovations.
The temple, managed by the Shrestha family, hosts several rituals, including worship during Sakimana Purnima, Holi, and a palanquin procession for Kumar during Dashain. (Shrestha, A. N. (2024, November 15). Insights on Kumar Temple [Interview with Ritual Custodian of the temple].) Despite its significance, there is no formal social trust overseeing the temple’s operations. After sustaining damage during the 2015 earthquakes, restoration efforts began in 2023 AD to preserve its architectural and cultural heritage.

monuments.name: Nhya Lho
monuments.history:
Located on the eastern side of Gahana Pokhari in Hadigaun, Nya Lho, meaning "fish stone," is a flat stone resembling a fish, believed to date back to the Lichhavi era. Beneath the stone lies an eye-shaped marking, enhancing its mystique. The monument holds profound cultural, social, and religious significance for the residents of Hadigaun.
Local legends enrich its lore. One speaks of a great flood in Adimakal (ancient times), after which the stone is said to be the remains of a massive fish that miraculously fed the villagers. Another legend recounts how a sage, facing potential harm during a famine, transformed into the fish-shaped stone to escape being consumed.
Religiously, Nya Lho is integral to the Tudaldevi Jatra. During the festival, the palanquin of Tudaldevi is placed on the stone before proceeding to Gahana Pokhari. The stone is believed to carry a curse, which is symbolically lifted when Toran Ajima’s Khat touches it during the Jatra.(Karmacharya, B. P. (2024, November 14). Insights on Tudal Devi Dyochhen [Interview with Ward Member, Ward No 5].) Additionally, the stone is venerated as Bhairav in the form of a fish, with an eye of Bhairav carved into it, further underscoring its sacred status.

monuments.name: Tisa Pukhu (Gahana Pokhari)
monuments.history:
Tisa Pukhu, also known as Gahana Pokhari or Ta Pukhu, is located in the southwestern part of Hadigaun, Kathmandu. Its name, translating to "Pond for the Search of Ornaments," reflects its association with the annual Tisa Maligu Jatra or Gahana Khojne Jatra, a festival dedicated to Toran Ajima (Tudal Devi). During this celebration, a ceremonial Khat is immersed in the pond, symbolizing the search for lost jewelry (Gahana), emphasizing its cultural and religious significance within the community (Tiwari, 2002).
Historically, Gahana Pokhari is believed to be one of the four ponds constructed by King Mandeva to support Hadigaun's settlement. These ponds, strategically placed near the Manmaneshwari Temple, formed part of a sophisticated water management system. Gahana Pokhari served as a reservoir, supplying water to local wells and a stone spout near the Satyanarayan Temple, highlighting its dual role in daily utility and sacred rituals (Tiwari, 2023). Its oval shape and strategic positioning suggest its importance as a sacred space and water resource, with historical ties to the Kailashkut Bhawan complex, an ancient royal palace. Even today, Tisa Pukhu continues to be an essential water source and plays a vital role in the social and spiritual life of Hadigaun, embodying a harmonious blend of practicality, spirituality, and cultural heritage.

monuments.name: Manmaneshwari Temple Premises
monuments.history:
The Manmaneshwari Temple, located in the southwestern corner of Hadigaun, is dedicated to Goddess Manmaneshwari. This two-storied temple, believed to originate during the reign of King Mandeva, enshrines the goddess in a copper pot (kalash), replacing a stolen golden pot. Serving as the tutelary deity of both the Licchavi and Malla kings, the temple holds great historical and cultural significance.
Architecturally, the temple is a Dyochhen (god-house) with a tiled roof. Its upper floor is vacant, while the ground floor houses the sanctum with carvings of Bhairava and Mahalakshmi on surviving struts. The sanctum contains a Bhagavati statue installed by King Bhaskar Malla in 1702 A.D and a unique Shivalinga, Maneshwar Mahadeva, notable for lacking a jalhari and receiving animal sacrifices. Other deities, including Ganesha, Kumar, and Annapurna, also form part of the shrine.
Historically, the temple played a prominent role during the Licchavi period, with King Mandeva adopting the goddess as his tutelary deity. An inscription from Aṃśuvarmā’s reign (608 CE) references Maneshwara, the male counterpart of the goddess, further underscoring its ancient roots. The tradition continued under the Malla kings, with significant contributions from King Bhaskar Malla and later recognition through tax exemptions by King Prithvi Narayan Shah in 1771 A.D and land grants by King Girvanayuddha in 1799 A.D.
Excavations in 1965 AD unearthed numerous artifacts, including Pashupati coins and stone seals from the reign of Aṃśuvarmā, affirming the temple's Licchavi origins. A 750 A.D water tank (Jarun Hiti), installed by Priyavarmana, was also discovered within the northern grounds, linking the site to the ancient settlement’s water management system.
The temple has enjoyed royal patronage and remains integral to local Newar clans such as the Pradhans, Mallas, Pradhanagas, Shresthas, Manandhars, and Rajbhansis, who venerate the goddess as their lineage deity. (Shrestha, R. (2024, November 14). Insights on Manmaneshwari Temple [Interview with Priest of the temple]). Annual rituals are performed between Akshaya Tritiya and Sithi Nakha, although its significance has diminished among worshippers outside these clans. Historically, rituals conducted by the Taleju Temple in Bhaktapur added to its prominence, but such traditions are no longer observed today. (Karmacharya, B. P. (2024, November 14). Insights on Manmaneshwari temple [Interview with Ward Member, Ward No 5].)

monuments.name: Tarini Devi Temple / Tarani Baha
monuments.history:
The Tarinidevi Temple, locally called Tana Bahah, is a Hindu Sakhta temple, despite the term “baha” in its name suggesting a Buddhist monastery. Established by Thakuri King Shankardev in 826 AD, it is maintained by 14 families descended from the Thaku Juju, who historically served as royal functionaries. The temple, predating the Taleju Temple (tutelary deity of the Malla Kings and the tallest temple in Hanumandhoka Durbar Square), is dedicated to Tarinidevi, associated with the forms of Goddess Tara: Ekajati, Nīlasaraswati, and Ugratara. (Hanumandhoka Durbar Museum Development Committee, 2019)
The temple’s origins are debated, with inscriptions attributing its establishment to Shankardev in 826 AD, though reliable records date to 1632 AD. Newar tradition regards Tarinidevi as Taleju’s elder sister, and historical accounts link her to royal protection. During King Mahendra Malla’s reign (16th c.), attempts to expand the Taleju Temple were reportedly obstructed by Tarinidevi’s displeasure.
Renovated in 2018 AD without government aid, the temple hosts significant rituals, including buffalo and duck sacrifices, while forbidding specific vegetables. It is central to the Dashain festival (around October), opens for public worship on Kartik's 1st bright fortnight, and celebrates its anniversary on Jyestha’s 10th bright fortnight. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Kalika Temple
monuments.history:
The Kalika Temple, adjacent to the Makhana Ganesh Temple, has undergone major changes, now enclosed within the private property of the Khanāla family as of April 2023 AD. Historical photos from 1956 AD depict the temple in an open space with a domed roof and long finial. In 2005 AD, the Khanāla family replaced the original structure with a concrete chamber, relocating the statues inside and incorporating the temple grounds into their residence.
The temple's original construction date is undocumented. Pruscha (1975, p.87) suggests it was built in the 20th century, describing it as a square sanctum with a domed roof and a torana depicting Mahishamardini. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Makhan Ganesh Temple
monuments.history:
The Ganesh Temple, located between Makhana Tol and Hanumandhoka, showcases a mix of architectural styles. The temple was remodeled during the 1987 SAARC summit in Kathmandu (BS 2044), funded by Divya Pradhan of Kulu Cuka, Makhana Tol. Previously, it followed the sikhara style with a prominent pinnacle, as seen in 1980s photographs and recalled by locals. A stone torana with Chepu, from the earlier design, is integrated into the current structure.
A Maharjan woman performs daily rituals at this primary Ganesh temple (SthanaGanesh) of Makhan Tol. It holds cultural significance, with locals seeking blessings before major events or ceremonies. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Mahendreswor Mahadev Temple
monuments.history:
The Mahendreswor Temple, also known as Makhan Pashupati Temple or Sano Pashupati, is a revered Shiva temple located in Makhan Tole, Kathmandu. This temple was commissioned in 1561 AD (Nepal Samvat 682) by King Mahendra Malla, who sought to establish a Paśupatinātha temple near his palace, similar to the Yaksheshwar Temple in Bhaktapur. Historical accounts suggest that Mahendra Malla followed the tradition set by King Yaksha Malla of Bhaktapur, who had built a Paśupati temple near his palace for daily worship. This act of devotion likely inspired Mahendra Malla to construct the Mahendreśvara Temple in Kathmandu (G. Vajracharya, BS 2033, p.79).
The temple’s two-tiered pagoda structure houses a four-faced śivaliṅga (Chaturmukhi Shiva Linga), symbolically representing Lord Pashupatinath. Historically, it also served as an alternative site for worship during floods that made access to the main Pashupatinath Temple near the Bagmati River difficult. This practical yet spiritual role elevated the temple's importance among devotees and earned it the affectionate name Makhana Pashupati .
Over the centuries, the Mahendreswor Temple has undergone significant renovations. A major restoration took place in 1963 AD (BS 2020), and a Shiva-Nandi statue was added in 2009 AD (BS 2066). Despite these changes, the temple has retained its architectural integrity, resembling Bhaktapur's Yaksheshwar Temple in its design and structure (Shrestha, 2013).
Today, the temple remains a prominent pilgrimage site, especially during Shivaratri and the auspicious month of Śrāvaṇa, drawing devotees from across the valley. The Mahendreśvara Temple stands as a testament to royal devotion, cultural continuity, and the architectural heritage of Kathmandu.

monuments.name: Mahavishnu Temple
monuments.history:
The Mahavishnu Temple in Hanumandhoka is a historic temple dedicated to Mahavishnu, and enshrines a gilded statue of the deity in its sanctum, depicting various incarnations such as Trailokyamohana, Pañcamukhī-Lakshminarayan, and Vaikuṇṭha-Vishnu.
The temple’s origins remain uncertain but are believed to be connected to King Jagajjaya Malla’s son, Rājendra Malla. The original three-tiered structure was reduced to two tiers after the catastrophic earthquakes of 1934 AD. During this time, the original Mahavishnu statue was relocated to Nāsaḥ Cuka for safekeeping.
A significant restoration effort was undertaken around 2003 AD, led by the Department of Archaeology and the Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust. This restoration sought to return the Mahavishnu Temple to its pre-1934 configuration using historical photographs as references. Key architectural elements such as the three tiers, traditional tiles, and gilded finial were reconstructed, while plain struts and a new Mahavishnu statue were added to the sanctum.
The temple suffered damage again during the 2015 Gorkha Earthquake. It was subsequently repaired, ensuring its preservation as a cultural and religious landmark in Hanumandhoka. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Kotilingeshwar Temple
monuments.history:
The Kotilingeswor Mahadev Temple, located in front of the KaalBhairav shrine at Hanumandhoka Durbar Square, is a south-facing stone structure built on three plinth levels. It features entrances on all four sides, with arched stone toranas depicting Chepu. Surrounding carvings include paired oxen with composite heads, reflecting Licchavi art influences. Adjacent elements include a dharmaśilā and a statue of Kāmadeva.
Commissioned by King Mahendra Malla in 1566 AD (NS 687), the temple was adorned with gold and inaugurated with a koṭīhoma ritual and Rāmāyaṇa dance. It was later granted lands by Queen Bhuvanalakṣmī, earning the title Bhuvaneśvara Temple, with 39 ropanīs of land under its Guthi. Originally built in a sikhara style in 1562 AD, its spires were destroyed by the 1746 earthquake and replaced with domes, and further damage in 1934 led to subsequent renovations.
Despite modifications, the temple remains a vital cultural and architectural landmark within Hanumandhoka Durbar Square. (Asian Historical Architecture, n.d.)

monuments.name: Kageswor Temple
monuments.history:
The Kageshwor Mahadev temple, originally named "Bhuvaneśvara" after its founder Bhuvanalakṣmī, is a distinctive temple combining elements from both the tiered and sikhara architectural styles.
Built in 1711 AD (NS 831) by Bhuvanalakṣmī, the temple was originally a stone structure with a four-faced śivaliṅga, indicating a primarily sikhara style. Over time, the structure underwent significant changes, especially following the 1833 earthquake, which resulted in the mixed architectural style seen today. Henry Oldfield’s 1858 painting depicts the temple in its current form, likely reflecting these alterations. (Asian Historical Architecture, n.d.)

Further damage occurred during the 1934 and 2015 earthquakes, both of which caused the temple to collapse completely. Between these events, the Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust (KVPT) restored the temple in 2006. After damages in 2015, the KVPT, in partnership with the Department of Archaeology, reconstructed the temple in 2018 with support from the US Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation.
Despite the transformations, the temple remains a key monument in Hanumandhoka Durbar Square, representing an architectural blend that emerged from successive restorations. Mary Slusser, an art historian, remarked on this fusion as "a very unfortunate architectural marriage," referring to the shift from a traditional multi-tiered Newar-style monument to a mixture of tiered and sikhara structure after the 1934 earthquake. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Mahadev Temple
monuments.history:
The southern Śiva temple, located near Siṃha Dhvākhā, the western entrance to the Taleju Temple in Kathmandu Durbar Square, is a west-facing, two-tiered structure with a traditional tiled roof topped by a metal finial. The sanctum houses a stone śivaliṅga, revered as Ānandeśvara Mahadev, according to the temple's priest, Pāṇḍe, a 67-year-old.
The original construction date of the temple is unclear. Pruscha (1975, p.55) suggests a likely 17th-century origin. A nearby northern Śiva temple has an inscription documenting its reconstruction in 2018 AD (BS 2074) after the 2015 earthquakes. The temple remains a significant yet understated monument within the religious and cultural landscape of Hanumandhoka Durbar Square. (NHDP, n.d.)
Situated to the north of the western entrance of the Taleju Temple (Siṃha Dhvākhā) in Kathmandu Durbar Square, Śiva Temple is a west-facing, two-tiered temple that houses a stone śivaliṅga, revered as Raṇamukteśvara Mahadev, as identified by the temple's priest, Pāṇḍe, a 67-year-old male.
Although the exact origins of the temple remain uncertain, Pruscha (1975, p.55) attributes its construction to the 17th century. Following the damage caused by the 2015 AD earthquakes, the temple was reconstructed in 2018 AD (BS 2074), as indicated by an inscription on its southwestern corner.
Daily rituals are no longer performed at this temple. Historically, priests from the Rājopādhyāya caste conducted worship, but since 2007 AD, this duty has transitioned to Pāṇḍe priests. Simple worship is now carried out only during specific occasions such as Shivaratri (February/March) and Dasaĩ (September/October). (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Taleju Bhawani Temple
monuments.history:
The Taleju Temple, also called the Taleju Bhawani Temple, is one of the oldest and most significant monuments in Hanuman Dhoka Durbar Square, constructed during the reign of King Mahendra Malla in 1563 AD. It holds a central position as the shrine dedicated to Taleju Bhawani, the patron goddess of the Malla dynasty. The temple's construction was part of a broader building initiative in Hanuman Dhoka Durbar Square by King Mahendra Malla, which also included other notable temples such as the Jagannath, Kotilingeswar Mahadev, and Mahendreswara temples.
Originally a goddess from South India, Taleju was brought to the Kathmandu Valley by the Malla kings. She replaced the earlier goddess Māneśvarī in the 14th century and became the guardian deity of the Malla rulers. The mantra associated with Taleju was believed to be essential for ensuring the continuity of royal rule and was passed down under specific conditions. The Malla kings established shrines dedicated to Taleju in each of their earlier independent states, including Bhaktapur and Patan, as well as in many other Newar settlements such as Dolakha and others.
The Taleju Temple has undergone several renovations over time. Initially constructed as a large, three-tiered structure, it underwent significant modifications during the 17th century under the patronage of King Pratap Malla, who added gilt copper paneling and further renovated the temple. The current architectural layout of the temple follows a cosmic mandala design, with a twelve-stepped base and sixteen satellite shrines surrounding the central sanctum.
Encircled by a high wall, the temple’s access is typically restricted to priests. Public entry is allowed only during special occasions such as Indra Jatra and Dashain, marking significant cultural and religious events in the Kathmandu Valley. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Panchamukhi Hanuman Temple
monuments.history:
The Panchamukhi Hanuman Temple is a unique example of a traditional Nepali circular tower, located in the northeast corner of the Hanumandhoka palace's Nasal Chowk, the largest and central courtyard of its eight courtyards.
The construction date of the temple is disputed, with some sources suggesting it was built in the early 19th century (Gutschow, p. 344), while others date it to 1655 (Pande), placing its origins during the late Malla or early Shah dynasty period. The temple is dedicated to Panchamukhi Hanuman, a five-faced form of the Hindu deity Hanuman. The tower itself features five circular tiered roofs, which are architecturally significant as circular tiered roofs are rare in the Kathmandu Valley. Only a handful of temples with this distinctive design can be found across the valley.
The symbolic significance of the number five is reflected throughout the temple. The name "Panchamukhi Hanuman" aligns with this theme, as Shrestha notes that in Newari, Panchamukhi Hanuman is often referred to by the word "nya," which carries the double meaning of "five" and "fish." (Asian Historical Architecture, n.d.).

monuments.name: Nautalle Durbar(Basantapur Tower)
monuments.history:
The Basantapur Tower, also known as the Nau Talle (Nine-Storied) Tower, is the tallest structure in Kathmandu's Hanumandhoka palace. It is believed to have been built during the reign of King Prithvi Narayan Shah (1723–1775) and his successor, King Pratap Singh Shah (1751–1777), over the foundation of an earlier Malla-era structure. This tower symbolizes the unification of the Kathmandu Valley, with each of the four corner towers representing one of the sub-kingdoms: Lalitpur, Bhaktapur, Kirtipur, and Kathmandu.
Though Gorkhali-born, the Shah kings embraced Newar arts and architecture, integrating local traditions into the design of the palace. The palace's quadrangular layout follows a Newar design precedent, dating back to the 12th century, which had been continuously developed and refined during the Malla period (12th–18th centuries).

monuments.name: Hanuman Stambha
monuments.history:
The Hanumān statue at the entrance of Hanuman Dhoka is a significant landmark, giving the palace complex its name, which means "entrance adorned with Hanuman." Covered in oil and vermilion powder, the statue features Hanumān in a blessing gesture (varada-mudrā) with his right hand and a protective gesture (abhaya-mudrā) with his left. Installed by King Pratap Malla in 1672 AD, the statue was believed to protect against diseases, natural calamities, and other dangers. Rituals are performed daily by the Karmācārya family, with special ceremonies held annually in Bhadra (August-September) and Chaitra (March-April). Devotees, especially those with children, offer butter lamps and garlands seeking protection from fear.
In recent years, the intricate details of the statue have been obscured due to layers of oil and vermilion applied during rituals. However, historical accounts and photographs reveal that the statue’s details were clearly visible a few decades ago. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Jagannath Temple
monuments.history:
The Jagannāth temple, also known as the Char Narayan or Carnarayan Temple, is one of the oldest and most significant Vaishnava temples in Hanumandhoka Durbar Square. It is built in Panchayana planning with the central temple surrounded by four temples in each of the corners. Positioned near the entrance of the Hanuman Dhoka palace, this temple was commissioned by King Mahendra Malla in 1563 AD. Originally, it was mistakenly attributed to King Pratap Malla (r. 1641-1674 AD) due to the installation of a Krishna (Jagannath) image during his reign. However, architectural historian Michael Hutt discovered that an inscription dated 1563 AD at the base of the temple’s central statue reveals that the temple predates Pratap Malla's reign, linking it to Mahendra Malla. (Asian Historical Architecture, n.d.)
Architecturally, the Jagannātha Temple is a two-tiered structure with traditional tile roofing, a walled sanctum featuring three portals on each side, and intricately carved toranas. Within the main sanctum, the central deity is a Caturvyūha Vishnu statue, depicting four distinct forms of Vishnu: Vāsudeva, Saṅkarṣaṇa, Pradyumna, and Aniruddha. The temple also houses statues of Krishna, SuBhadra, and Balarāma, aligning it with the Jagannātha tradition found at the cāradhāma site in Puri, India because of which the temple got its name as Jagannath temple.
This temple is one of four major structures commissioned by Mahendra Malla in the Durbar Square, the others being Kotilingeswar Mahadev, Mahendreswara, and the Taleju Temple. (Bajracharya, 1976)

monuments.name: Pratap Malla Stambha
monuments.history:
The Pratāp Malla Stambha, located in front of the Śvetabhairava temple at Hanumandhoka Durbar Square, is a prominent stone pillar erected by King Pratap Malla in 1670 AD. The pillar, known as 'Pratapdhvaja' or the Banner of Pratap, features a statue of the king surrounded by smaller statues of his consorts, Anantapriyā and Pravāvatī, and his sons. Pratap Malla was known for his innovative and unconventional endeavors, such as his interest in diverse scripts and his unique architectural contributions. The pillar marks a departure from traditional pillars, which typically featured divine vehicles rather than human figures, setting a trend followed by subsequent rulers. The inscription on the pillar lists the names of the princes and details Pratap Malla's offerings to the deity Taleju Māju, including golden pinnacles, an umbrella, and statues, alongside a land endowment for the pillar's maintenance. The statues' attire reflects Mogul influences, with Pratap Malla depicted in meditation, wearing a serpent-shaped crown.
The pillar was affected by the 2015 earthquake and the idols on top of it were reinstalled. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Gopinath Temple (Sri Krishna Maha Vishnu Temple)
monuments.history:
The main deity of the temple is a composite statue of Vishnu and his incarnation Krishna, known as Shreekrishna Mahavishnu. The gilded statue, located in a three-tiered temple west of the Taleju temple at Hanumāna Ḍhokā, stands on three plinths with an entrance on all four sides, facing east. The ground floor has a three-bayed ambulatory on all sides, and the four-armed statue of Shreekrishna Mahavishnu carries a discus (cakra) and a conch (śaṅkha) shell with his secondary arms; with his principal arms placed in front of his chest as if he holds a flute. The cakra and śaṅkha represent Vishnu, while the flute, which is no longer intact on the statue, represents Krishna. (G. Bajracharya BS 2033, p.84).
Although Pruscha (1975, p. 62) identifies the temple as a 17th-century structure, there is no historical source that dates its initial construction. However, a manuscript records King Pratap Malla offering a cakra to a Vishnu temple in 1666 AD, which appears to be this one (G. Bajracharya BS 2033, p.84).
Miśra brahmins conduct daily rituals at the temple, and on Kṛṣṇāṣṭamī, the 8th day of the dark fortnight of Bhadra, metal statue of Krishna is taken around the Hanumāna Ḍhokā area on a palanquin. Additionally, a ceremonial pole (yaḥsĩ) is erected next to the temple on the 12th day of the bright fortnight, marking the beginning of the Yẽnyāḥ festival in Kathmandu. In the past, the Śāha kings used to sit on the ambulatory of the temple to witness the erection of yaḥsĩ. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Kaal Bhairab Shrine
monuments.history:
The shrine of Kal Bhairav, prominently located in the heart of Hanumandhoka Durbar Square, is one of Nepal's most iconic cultural and spiritual landmarks. Depicting the fierce form of Lord Shiva, this stone monument serves as a powerful symbol of divine justice, protection, and truth. Experts examining its intricate craftsmanship date the creation of the statue to the 7th century, during the Licchavi period, although it was installed in its current location in the 17th century by the legendary King Pratap Malla (HMG Department of Archaeology, Kathmandu Metropolitan City, & Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust, 2005; Bajracharya, n.d.).
Known as the “Court Bhairav,” this shrine historically played a central role in Nepal’s judicial system. Until the Rana period, individuals in legal disputes or serious conflicts were brought before Kal Bhairav to take oaths of truth. It was believed that any false statement made in the deity’s presence would result in divine retribution. This practice, deeply rooted in cultural beliefs, reinforced Kal Bhairav’s authority as the ultimate seer of truth and a protector of justice in the Kathmandu Valley (Setopati, 2024).
The colossal stone image of Kal Bhairav is a remarkable piece of art that exudes divine power and authority. The deity is portrayed with six arms, each holding symbolic objects that signify his destructive and protective powers. These include weapons and ritual implements that evoke his fierce aspect as the destroyer of evil forces. His open mouth displays his sharp teeth and protruding tongue, a characteristic feature symbolizing his ferocity. Kal Bhairav stands adorned with a garland of skulls, representing his transcendence over life and death, and his expression is both fearsome and captivating, evoking awe and reverence (Setopati, 2024).
The intricate details of the statue’s craftsmanship—particularly its bold carving, intricate ornamentation, and harmonious proportions—are hallmarks of Licchavi-period artistry. The vibrant colors applied to the stone figure by devotees during religious rituals add a dynamic element to its appearance, making it a living symbol of devotion.
Legend holds that the image was discovered during the excavation of a water conduit at Buddha Nilkantha and brought to Kathmandu by King Pratap Malla. While this story remains unverified, the statue’s stylistic and technical details confirm its origins in the 7th century, a time of flourishing stone craftsmanship in the Kathmandu Valley. Gautama Vajra Bajracharya, in his detailed accounts of Hanumandhoka, highlights the ancient origins of this masterpiece, underscoring its deep historical and artistic value (Bajracharya, n.d.).

monuments.name: Indrapur Temple
monuments.history:
Indrapur is a sattal-like temple with an open plan upper level, directly adjacent to the Vishnu temple from 1667. Unusually, it defies the typical convention that forbids worshippers from occupying a floor above the enshrined deity, though in recent years, access to the balcony has been restricted. As noted by Bernier, as late as the 1970s, the upper level was occasionally used to display a statue of Indra during the annual Indra Jatra festival. The windowless square sanctum on the ground floor includes an entrance on the south side and a shiva lingam along the north wall. Access to the interior is generally prohibited.
According to Michael Hutt, the Indrapur may be a stand-in for the much grander Indreshwar Mahadev at Panuati, allowing worshippers to accrue the benefits of "visiting" that site by worshiping at this smaller substitute temple. (Nepal Heritage Documentation Project, n.d.)

monuments.name: Lakshmi Narayan Temple
monuments.history:
The Lakshminarayan Temple, located directly west of the Jagannath Temple in Hanumandhoka, is a two-tiered Newar-style tiered built during the reign of Pratap Malla (r. 1641-74). Dedicated to Vishnu as Narayana alongside Lakṣmī, the temple is square in plan with entrances on all four sides, though only the west and south are visible due to its proximity to the Kaal Bhairav image.
The temple suffered damage in the 1934 AD earthquake and was reconstructed in the early 1940s under Prime Minister Juddha Śamśera with further renovations occurring in the 1950s and again in 2007. It was restored once more after the 2015 AD earthquake. The temple remains mostly closed to visitors, with no reported socio-cultural activities or priestly services taking place within. (Ranjitkar & Joshi, 2007)

monuments.name: Degu Talle Temple
monuments.history:
The Degu Tale Temple, standing 62 haat tall, was historically reserved for Malla kings to perform the Dewali (Digu Puja), as it was the Istadevata (main deity) of the royal family of Malla Kings. Due to its royal significance, public entry was restricted.
According to the Bhasa Bansawali, the temple was originally constructed by King Shiva Singh. In B.S. 1727 Bhadra, King Pratap Malla renovated the temple, adding a golden roof and gajur (pinnacle). This temple uniquely stands on the terrace of a three storey structure and has four highly decorated, three-faced doors, with the main entrance facing south. The north-facing door was later silver-coated by Shri 5 Girvan Yuddha Bikram in B.S. 1872. While most temples typically feature an odd number of gajurs (1, 3, or 5), this temple originally had six, as mentioned in Pratap Malla’s inscription on the pillar in front of the temple. Today, five gajurs remain—four at the corners and one at the center. The temple is traditionally believed to have been established on Akshaya Tritiya, and a special puja is held annually on this day (Bajracharya, 1976).

monuments.name: Swet Bhairab Temple
monuments.history:
The Swet Bhairav statue, situated adjacent to the Degu Taleju temple, is fully revealed to the public only during the Yenyaa or Indra Jatra festival. Historical inscriptions indicate that the statue was established by King Rana Bahadur Shah in 1852 B.S. However, its origins are believed to date back earlier. According to local accounts, the statue was initially made of stone, but after the death of his son, a grief-stricken Ran Bahadur Shah funded the gold plating for the statue.
Before being unveiled for Indra Jatra, the statue undergoes special rituals and sacrifices, along with a repainting process. Sundaranand Wada, in his text Triratna Saundarya Gaatha, described Swet Bhairav as "Sharavmukh Bhairav" and explained its purpose—to enhance the grandeur of Indra Jatra and protect against dakini, ghosts, and evil spirits.
Historical financial records reveal that the gold used for the statue cost 4,000 rupees when the price of one tola of gold was 18 rupees.
During Indra Jatra, crowds gather around the mask of Swet Bhairav to drink sacred liquor that flows from its mouth through a small pipe. This liquor, believed to prevent illness, is served over all eight days of the festival. Alcohol is offered on the day of the full moon (Purnima), while rice beer is served on the other nights. Approximately 80 liters of liquor are distributed daily during the festival (Bajracharya, 1976)(Tamrakar, 2024).

monuments.name: Chyasin Dega [Vamsha Gopal (Krishna) Temple]
monuments.history:
The Cyāsiṃdegaḥ, also known as the Krishna Temple or Vaṃśagopāla Temple, is an octagonal monument located northwest of the Hanuman Dhoka palace in Kathmandu. Commissioned by King Pratap Malla in 1649 AD (NS 769), this temple was built to commemorate the king and his deceased queens, Rūpamatī and Rājamatī. The name "Cyāsiṃ" is derived from the local term "cyāsiliṃ," meaning "eight edges," which corresponds to its distinctive octagonal structure.
The main entrance faces east, leading to the sanctum where statues of Krishna, flanked by his consorts Rukmiṇī and Satyabhāmā, are enshrined. These statues symbolically represent King Pratap Malla and his two late queens, an unusual act in history where a ruler deifies himself and his spouses. (Bajracharya, 1976)
In front of the temple, two stone pillars stand, one of which bears a damaged statue of Hanumān. The second pillar’s statue has been lost over time.
A special worship and celebration takes place during Krishna Janmasthami as well.(Asian Historical Architecture, n.d.)

monuments.name: Saraswati Temple
monuments.history:
At first glance, the Saraswati Falcha resembles a square-shaped structure, known locally as a mandaḥ, a type of structure common in the Kathmandu Valley and surrounding areas. However, unlike the typical mandaḥ phalcā, which is always free-standing and open on all sides, the Saraswati Falcha is attached to a brick wall on its western side.
The rear wall of the Phalcā contains a small, enclosed chamber that serves as a sanctum housing a medieval statue of Sarasvatī. This sanctum can be accessed through an artistically carved wooden door. The statue of Sarasvatī depicts the goddess with four arms, seated in the lalitāsana posture. In her two upper arms, she holds an akṣamāla (prayer beads) and a scripture, while her primary right and left hands display the varada-mudrā (gesture of granting boons) and abhaya-mudrā (gesture of fearlessness), respectively.
There are no historical records that precisely date the original construction of the Phalcā, but the wood carvings suggest that it was built in the mid-to-late 17th century. Uniquely, the outer sides of the Phalcā's nināḥs are adorned with carvings of various Hindu deities and figures, while the inner sides are also decorated, a rare feature for such structures. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Taga Gan Bell
monuments.history:
The Taḥgaḥ Gaṃ, a large bell located in Hanumandhoka Durbar Square, was installed in 1797 AD (BS 1854) by King Raṇabahādura and dedicated to Goddess Taleju. Similar bells had been established earlier in Bhaktapur and Patan by King Bhupatīndra Malla and King Vishnu Malla, respectively. These bells, dedicated to Taleju, were placed on elevated platforms to project their sound over long distances. They served various purposes, such as making announcements, marking time, and intimidating adversaries. In Kathmandu, the bell is rung during the morning rituals at Degu Taleju temple.
Traditionally, the bell is rung 108 times every morning at 9 AM and 365 times during the evening of Mha Puja. Other rituals associated with this bell include the annual puja during Saraswati Puja, rituals during Dashain and Tihar, and special offerings during Indra Jatra, particularly for the three chariots.
The practice of ringing the Taḥgaḥ Gaṃ was disrupted in 1933 AD (BS 1990) when one of the bell’s chains broke. Though briefly repaired, it eventually fell silent for decades. In 2009 AD (BS 2066), the tradition was revived with Bābu Krishna Maharjan entrusted to ring the bell 108 times every morning at 9 AM and continues till date. (Maharjan, 2024).

monuments.name: Layaku Bahil
monuments.history:
Layaku Bahi, located in the Hanumandhoka Durbar area, was built by a merchant from ItumBahah and named for its proximity to the palace. It operates as a branch of Sikhomu Bahah, with the Bajracharyas of Sikhomu Bahah managing it. The architecture deviates from typical Bahīs, featuring a three-story main shrine with a corrugated metal roof, a Bajracharya family on the second floor, and a gāndhakuti on the ground floor.
The courtyard houses an Ashoka Stupa, Shikharkut Stupa, and a donor's statue. The oldest inscription dates to Nepal Samvat 855 (1734 AD). The most recent renovation occurred in 1898 AD when Lakshmi Thakum added a torana.
Layaku Bahi is not part of the 15 Bahīs in Kathmandu but is associated with the Bajracharyas, who participate in key rituals like the Kalewar Hillegu Puja and the restoration of Swoyambhu Mahachaitya. Rituals are managed by Udayaman, a single Bajracharya, with annual visits from the donor's descendants for worship (NHDP, n.d.).

monuments.name: Shiva Parvati/ Nava Yogini Temple
monuments.history:
The Shiva-Parvati temple is a rectangular, two-story building, facing south, standing directly northeast of the much larger Maju Dega temple of 1690, which was destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. Unlike most temples in Nepal, it is built with only one roof. According to Ronald Bernier, this is typical of shrines intended as votive offerings.
The temple was constructed at the tail end of the 18th-century during Rana Bahadur Shah's rule (r. 1777-99). Michael Hutt notes that it "blends harmoniously with the Malla-period architecture that surrounds it." (Hutt, p. 88). Hutt opines that it was likely built by Bahadur Shah, the youngest son of Prithvi Narayan, the founder of the Kingdom of Nepal (Bahadur is not to be confused with Ran Bahadur, who was Prithvi's grandson by a different brother). (Asian Historical Architecture, n.d.)
The monument is widely characterized as the Shiva-Parvati temple as the upper level features a pair of mannequins of Shiva and Parvati, seemingly gazing south across the square. However, the temple's formal name is the Navadurga, referring to nine manifestations of the goddess Durga whose likenesses are housed on the ground-level floor. These goddesses are not visible to the public. Although the front facade contains five doors, only the central door is operational and is usually kept locked. As with most Nepali temples, the interior is only open to priests and temple custodians.

monuments.name: Bhagwati Temple
monuments.history:
Bhagawati Temple is located near the southwest corner of the Hanuman Dhoka Palace compound, facing west towards the street, opposite the Shiva-Parvati or Navagdurga Temple. The temple is one of the few structures attributed to Jagajjaya Malla, who ruled Kathmandu from 1722 to 1736 AD. The construction of the Bhagawati Temple is believed to have been an attempt by Jagajjaya Malla to legitimize his rule by associating himself with the earlier Malla kings, particularly Pratap Malla (1641-1674 AD).
According to Michael Hutt in Nepal: A Guide to the Art and Architecture of the Kathmandu Valley, the temple originally housed a statue of the god Narayan, which Jagajjaya Malla called Mahipatindreshvar (Lord of Mahipatindra). The name was chosen to honor Mahipatendra Malla, a murdered king who was the heir of the great King Pratap Malla.
The original Narayan image was stolen in 1767 and never returned. In its place, Prithvi Narayan Shah, the first monarch of the Kingdom of Nepal, installed an image of Bhagawati (Durga) that he had taken from Nuwakot. Despite the replacement, the statue of Bhagawati is returned to Nuwakot for a brief period each April, a tradition that continues to this day.
This temple thus holds historical and religious significance as both a symbol of Jagajjaya Malla's political maneuvering and the evolving traditions of Nepal's early rulers (Asian Historical Architecture, n.d.; NHDP, n.d.).

monuments.name: Joshi Aagan Temple
monuments.history:
The Jośī Āgaṃchẽ, a three-story building in Kathmandu's Maru Tol, serves as the residence of the Dvaja Jośī clan’s secret deity (āgaṃdyaḥ). This structure is central to the clan’s rituals, with access to the deity’s chamber restricted to those initiated through tantric rites. The building, which faces east, features intricate carvings on the upper levels and latticed windows on the second floor. The ground floor has an ornate entrance framed by a torana. Currently, the ground floor and parts of the upper floors have shops and restaurants.
Though the Āgaṃchẽ’s origins are unclear, its medieval architecture and wooden carvings suggest a long history. The roof was replaced with copper sheets in 2006 AD. Damaged in the 2015 earthquake, the building was restored by 2019
The Sanātana Īṣṭadevatā Guthī, a trust of 100 members, manages the Āgaṃchẽ, performing daily rituals and hosting an annual feast for clan members during Mārgaśīrṣa. This building remains a vital center for the Dvaja Jośī clan's spiritual practices (NHDP, n.d.).

monuments.name: Maju Dega Temple
monuments.history:
Maju Dega is a three-tiered Newari-style temple dedicated to Shiva, built in B.S. 1747 by Queen Riddhi Lakshmi during her grandson Bhupalendra Malla's reign. Tragically, Bhupalendra Malla died at the age of 21 after ascending the throne at eight. The temple stands on a nine-level pyramidal plinth and is distinguished by a unique finial or pinnacle, a white Buddha stupa, atop its three-tiered roof. (Bajracharya, 1976)
According to the Kathmandu Post, the temple was a popular gathering place in the 1970s for foreign visitors, chiefly because its lofty vantage point provided an ideal spot to view the surrounding Hanuman Dhoka square

monuments.name: Garuda Narayan Temple
monuments.history:
The Garudnarayan Satah, located east of Maru Ganesh, was originally built as a Satah, not a temple. A two-story temple addition with a statue of Lakshminarayan was later added, making it also known as the Lakshminarayan temple. The Satah features a statue of Garudnarayan on its top floor, likely inspiring its name. Its structure resembles a satah, with columns surrounding the ground level, and houses statues of Siṃhanāda Lokeśvara and another Lokeśvara in its sacred chambers. The intricate torana above the entrance depicts a meditating Buddha with two sages.
The Satah's southern first-floor windows and struts, decorated with Naṛasiṃha and Varāha, suggest it dates back to the 16th or early 17th century. Oral histories mention that a Bahah once stood here, housing the same Lokeśvara deity now in the Satah. Cautāriyā Lakshminarayan Jośī is believed to have built it during King Bhupālendra Malla's reign.
The Satah is currently in a dilapidated state, with disputes halting reconstruction. The top floor is inaccessible due to fragility, preventing viewing of the Garudnarayan statue as of May 2023 (NHDP, n.d.).

monuments.name: Ashoka Binayak Temple
monuments.history:
Aśoka Vināyaka, is one of the four principal Ganesh shrines in the Kathmandu Valley, located in Maru Ṭole, the shrine is referred to as Maru Ganesh, with the additional name "Gajūmaru Ganesh," meaning "Ganesh without a finial," owing to the absence of a finial atop its structure. This modest single-story shrine, facing south, houses an idol of Ganesh under a sanctum with a gilded roof and a silver-covered stone arch (torana). The idol keeps getting replaced as per occasions or special days. The shrine's outer walls are covered in brass sheets, and it is guarded by stone and metal lions. A brass statue of Ganesh's companion, a mouse, stands in front. The shrine is enclosed by metal bars for circulation .
Believed to have been built beneath an Aśoka tree, the shrine is also known as Aśoka Vināyaka. It was left incomplete, and the gilded roof was added by Vishnusiṃ Mānandhara's family in 1847 AD. The shrine suffered minor damage in the 1934 earthquake but was repaired. In 2012 AD, the Aśoka Vināyaka Guthi trust undertook reconstruction .
Daily rituals are conducted by a Bajracharya priest, and the shrine is maintained by the Jyapu community. Notable events include a palanquin procession during Dashain and Ganesh's birthday on the 4th day of Bhadra, celebrated with a traditional feast. Maru Ganesh is believed to have been constructed by Gundakama Deva in the 10th century, with its origins possibly dating back to the 5th-8th centuries AD. (Banjara, 2023).

monuments.name: Durga Temple
monuments.history:
The Durga Temple, located west of the Maru Ganesh Temple, features a two-tiered structure with traditional tiled roofs and intricate wooden carvings. The sanctum houses a statue of Bhagavatī, revered as Durga in her ten-armed Mahiṣāsuramardinī form. The temple's origin is unclear, though the carvings suggest a later-medieval period. The 2015 earthquakes caused damage, but the temple was restored in 2018 by the Department of Archaeology and the Sanātana Iṣṭadevatā Guthi.
Annual rituals include an animal sacrifice by the Jośīs from Maru Tol in Mārgaśīrṣa and special worship in Māgha. Maintenance is handled by a Jyapu clan, and a money exchanger operates a temporary shop on the temple's plinth. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Maru Satah(Kasthamandap)
monuments.history:
Kasthamandap, a wooden pavilion in Kathmandu, is an architectural masterpiece that gave the city its name. Known locally as "Maru Satah," it stands out as the largest Satah in the valley and features an open ground floor, unlike other rest houses. The term "maru" likely originates from "mandap," meaning pavilion. The structure’s various names reflect its rich history, including “Yaṅgramando” during the Licchavi period.
Believed to have been built primarily from a single sāla tree, the structure is supported by four massive pillars and has three tiers. The ground floor houses a statue of Gorakhnath, likely installed in the 14th century, alongside four Ganesh statues at its corners. Nearby landmarks are also named after Kasthamandap, emphasizing its central role in the area’s cultural identity.
The exact date of its construction is debated. While some sources suggest it was built during King Lakshminarasimha Malla's reign (1619-1641 AD), references in earlier manuscripts date the structure back to at least the 11th century. Legends connect its creation to the wish-fulfilling tree, Kalpavṛkṣa, which provided the timber for its construction in 1595 AD.
Kasthamandap’s relationship with ascetics dates back to the 15th century, when land donations began supporting their residence there. In the 20th century, the structure housed ascetic communities, who collected rent from shops within it. The site was a hub for public announcements and rituals, highlighting its societal importance.
In 2015, the structure collapsed during a devastating earthquake, killing ten people and burying many inscriptions. Excavations revealed that its foundation dates back to the 7th century. Reconstruction began in 2018 and was completed in 2022, though the site remains closed due to ongoing legal disputes over the replacement of damaged statues. (Bajracharya, 1976)

monuments.name: Mahadev Temple
monuments.history:
The Mahadev Temple, located in Gaḥkuti near Kabindrapur, is a sikhara-style brick temple believed to have originated in the 15th century, though no definitive source confirms this. The temple has undergone several renovations, including after the 1934 earthquake and most recently in 2013-14 through a collaboration between the local community and Kathmandu Metropolis, which altered the upper structure. Despite these changes, some original elements like stone pillars, a wooden arch (torana), and terra cotta kinnara statues remain, indicating its later-medieval origins. The sanctum houses a stone śivaliṅga as the principal deity.
Once significant in the local socio-religious context, the temple's daily rituals were maintained by a family from the Udaya community until the early 1990s. However, the temple is now neglected, with no regular rituals except for a bonfire lit by locals during Shivaratri. Despite its historic importance, the temple currently lacks care and attention. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Silyan Satah
monuments.history:
Silyan Satah, originally constructed from leftover timber from the Kasthamandap building, is a multi-storied rest house. The name "Silyan Satah" translates to "rest house built from surplus timber." In 1929 AD (BS 1986), large winged lion statues were added, and the building was renamed Siṃha Satah ("lion rest house"). Located south of Kasthamandap, it features a three-story structure with a tiled roof and gilded finial. The second floor has a veranda and houses a Vaṃśīdhara Krishna statue, accompanied by statues of Ganesh and another Krishna. Uniquely, a Garuḍa statue is placed inside rather than outside the building, a common feature in Vaiṣṇava temples.
Legend suggests the timber used for construction came from a sāla tree (Shorea robusta), with any excess buried between Silyan Satah and Kasthamandap. After a fire destroyed Subbā Dharmanārāyaṇa Mānandhar's house, a Krishna statue was discovered, later enshrined in the rest house by his son, Harṣanārāyaṇa, who established a social trust (guthi) to maintain rituals.
The original design of the building is unknown, but the current structure was a renovation by Harṣanārāyaṇa Mānandhar, who added seventeen ground-floor rooms to generate income for rituals. Winged lion statues were added in 1929 AD (BS 1986) by Jogamāyā Mānandhar in memory of her son, leading to the name change. Following the takeover by Guthi Saṃsthāna, the building's condition and cultural activities declined due to insufficient funding. A restoration project, interrupted by the 2015 AD earthquakes, was completed in 2017 AD (BS 2074). As of March 2023 AD, the ground floor operates as a Tourist Information Center managed by Kathmandu Metropolis (NHDP, n.d.).

monuments.name: Kavindrapur Dhansa
monuments.history:
Kabindrapur, also known as Nasahdyah Temple or Dhansa, is located on the east side of Maru Tol Square, southwest of Hanuman Dhoka Palace in Kathmandu. Built in 1657 AD (NS 777) by King Pratap Malla, it was originally one of the tallest structures in Kathmandu Durbar Square. The name Kabindrapur, meaning "Mansion of Kavindra," refers to Pratap Malla's self-given title, "Lord of Poets."
This three-tiered building blends a temple and a Satah (rest house) design. The structure is topped with traditional tile roofs and three finials. Its ground floor features 13 arcaded bays, with the middle seven extending outward to form a prominent upper balcony (pula). The original building had an additional tier, which was lost during the 1934 earthquake.
The main deity on the ground floor is Nasahdyah, the god of music and drama, represented by a small triangular hole in the wall. Other deities, including Narasiṃha, Bhringi, and Chamunda, are also enshrined. The top level holds a shrine to Bhavanishankar, representing the Vaishnav triad of Jagannath, SuBhadra, and BalaBhadra. The temple holds historical significance, as King Pratap Malla built it to appease Narasiṃha, who was angered by the king impersonating him in a dance. The king installed a statue of Narasimha alongside Nasahdyah.
A Shakya woman currently performs daily rituals at the Nasahdyah shrine. The temple plays a key role in Kathmandu's cultural life, particularly for traditional music and dance training. Every 12 years, mask dances of Bhadrakālī from Naradevī and Khokanā are performed in front of Kabindrapur, with dance troupes residing in the temple’s upper hall. Kabindrapur remains a testament to King Pratap Malla’s devotion, creativity, and the cultural vibrancy of his reign. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Bimaleshwar Mahadev Shrine
monuments.history:
The Bimaleshwar Mahadev Temple, situated in Kathmandu's Maru Tole, was built in NS 814 (1693 AD) by Vimaleshwardas, a resident of the same area. The temple lies to the east of Kasthamandap and west of the Pum Dega (Trailokya Mohan Temple).
Bimaleshwardas not only built the temple but also endowed it with land as a guthi (trust) to fund regular worship and other rituals. Income generated from the land was intended to sustain daily worship and special festival rituals.
When establishing the temple, Vimaleshwardas stipulated that on the day of Shivaratri, the Shivalinga should be worshipped with panchamrit, and lamps should be lit. Similarly, lamps were to be lit throughout the duration of Indra Jatra. On the temple's annual anniversary, after feeding Brahmins, Joshis, and Acharyas (Karmacharyas), lamps were to be lit in the evening.
Any leftover funds from these rituals were to be used for the temple’s maintenance. However, these religious activities are no longer regularly conducted as originally inscribed on the stone slab. Daily worship has been suspended since the earthquake, though the special Shivaratri worship continues uninterrupted. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Trailokya Mohan Narayan Temple
monuments.history:
The Trailokya Mohan Narayan Temple, also known as the Dasavatar Dekhaune Mandir, is a significant monument in Hanuman Dhoka Durbar Square, Kathmandu. This elegant three-tiered-style temple was constructed in 1680 AD (NS 801) by King Parthivendra Malla to honor his deceased brother, King Nripendra Malla.
