Located near the Gaddi Baithak and northwest of the Kumari Ghar, the temple is dedicated to Vishnu in the form of Trailokya Mohan, symbolizing Vishnu as the "Lord of the Three Worlds." The structure features a central sanctum housing an eight-armed Vishnu (Trailokya Mohan Narayan) holding Lakshmi in his lap, with Garuda depicted beneath. (Asian Historical Architecture, n.d.)
In front of the temple, a rare Malla-period Garuda statue kneels in a prayerful posture facing the temple. Installed in 1689 AD by Queen Riddhi Lakshmi (Nripendra Malla's widow), the statue is noted for its remarkable craftsmanship and lifelike detail.
The temple is also known for the annual Dasavatar (Ten Incarnations of Vishnu) exhibition during the Indra Jatra festival, where the Manandhar community of Maru Tole showcases lively displays of Vishnu's avatars. Due to this tradition, the temple is colloquially called the "Dasavatar Dekhaune Mandir." (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Sikhamu Bahal
monuments.history:
Sikhomu Bahah or Shreekhanda Taramul Mahavihar, believed to have been established by Līlāvajra around 741 AD, is one of the oldest and most significant Buddhist monasteries in Kathmandu, though historical records confirm its existence from NS 492 (1372 AD). Located in the Layaku area (Hanuman Dhoka Royal Palace region), it is situated west of the Kumari Bahah in Basantapur. Inside the sanctum is a stone statue of Maitreya Buddha, which replaced an older wooden statue.
The monastery is home to five Licchavi-era chaityas and is also historically significant as the residence of the Royal Guru, who served at the Hanuman Dhoka Palace during the medieval period. The name "Sikhomu" is believed to derive from a pile of logs used for the construction of Kasthamandap. Some locals speculate that it was built from the roots of a sandalwood tree, based on its Sanskrit name, Shreekhanda Taramul Mahavihar.
While the historical evidence of its construction is sparse, the earliest confirmed reference to Sikhomu Bahah appears in an inscription from NS 492 (1372 AD). The monastery’s Royal Guru, Gyanakīrti, played a role in overseeing rituals following the 1349 AD invasion by Sultan Shamsuddin of Bengal, which damaged the Swoyambhu Stupa. Over the centuries, scholars and priests from Sikhomu Bahah have contributed to religious texts and rituals.
The monastery's land once spanned from Kal Bhairav to Atko Narayan, but portions were appropriated during the reign of Jayaprakash Malla for the construction of the Kumari House. After the 1934 earthquake, further land was seized, with several Bahahs relocated, including to Ranamuktishwor.
Traditionally, the Royal Guru from Sikhomu Bahah led rituals at the Hanuman Dhoka Palace, but this role was shifted to the Brahmin Pāṇḍes after Prithvi Narayan Shah’s conquest. The cultural significance of the Royal Guru continues, with the current Royal Guru, Manjushriratna Bajracharya, performing daily rituals at the Kumari House. Rituals such as Kīkālā Guthi and Pohēlā Guthi are also part of the monastery's traditions (NHDP, n.d.).

monuments.name: Kumari Bahal
monuments.history:
Kumari Bahah, also known as Kumari Chĕ or Kumari Ghar, is the residence of the living Kumari, a young girl revered as a goddess in both Hindu and Buddhist traditions. The term Kumari Chĕ highlights its role as the abode of the Kumari, who is considered the living embodiment of Taleju Bhawani. In addition to this, it is historically identified as Rājakīrti Manorama Vihara, possibly named after a king who built it to ensure his lasting fame. It is also known as Rājalakṣmī Vihara in Vajrayāna Buddhism, where the goddess Vasundharā, equated with both Kumari and Lakṣmī, is worshiped.
The origin of the Kumari tradition in Nepal is rooted in a tale from the Malla period. King Jaya Prakash Malla, who secretly played a game of dice with Goddess Taleju every night, was bound by a strict rule: he could not reveal this to anyone, not even a hint. However, his wife grew suspicious of his nightly absences and decided to follow him one evening. She discovered the king with the goddess in a secluded room, playing the game. The queen’s intrusion angered
Taleju, and as a result, the goddess disappeared. Despite the king’s pleas and rituals to bring her back, Taleju declared that she would not return but would instead reside within a girl of the Shakya community. Thus, the tradition of the Kumari began, with a young girl chosen to embody the goddess Taleju, and the custom has continued to this day as an important spiritual and cultural practice in Nepal.
Architecturally, Kumari Bahah is a three-story Vihara featuring an open courtyard. The entrance is guarded by two stone lions, and intricate carvings of deities, such as Ganesh, Bhairava, and Mahiṣamardinī Dūrgā, symbolize Taleju Bhawani. The upper floors have beautifully carved lattice windows, including the central Kumari jhya, which is gilded. Inside, the sanctum houses the kvāpādyaḥ of Pañca Buddha along with statues of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. The Vihara has dalānas (verandas) providing access to rooms and ritual spaces, including the Kumari's bedroom and the āgamakōṭhā for special pūjās.
Kumari Bahah is not only the Kumari's residence but also a vibrant center of cultural activities. Various pūjās and festivals, including Dashain and Indra Jatra, are conducted, and the Kumari plays an essential role in the chariot procession, paraded through Kathmandu accompanied by other deities and traditional dancers. Kumari Bahah thus remains a symbol of Kathmandu's rich cultural and spiritual heritage (KMC Ward 23 Office, n.d.).

monuments.name: Gaddi Baithak
monuments.history:
The Gaddi Baithak, a modern Neo-classical style building within Hanumandhoka Palace, stands in Nhuchen Chowk, where Prithvi Narayan Shah entered the palace after conquering Kathmandu. The name "Nhuchen Chowk" refers to "the chowk with the new house," as mentioned in the records of King Jayaprakash Malla.
In BS 1904, Jung Bahadur Rana demolished a house in this chowk and constructed a new building blending Newari and modern styles, known as Nolsi Durbar. The upper floor housed a grand meeting room, LalBaithak, where formal ceremonies were held, including medal exchanges and meetings with foreign representatives.
In BS 1965, Chandra Shumsher demolished the LalBaithak and built the current Gaddi Baithak, where the Rajgaddi (royal throne) has been kept in the meeting room. The design was by Kishore Narsingh and Kumar Narsingh Rana, who also designed Singha Durbar. The European-style building features a grand staircase, though its initial placement near the Kumari house caused difficulties for worship, prompting a redesign.
The Gaddi Baithak suffered damage from earthquakes, including the 1990 earthquake, after which it was swiftly rebuilt. It was again damaged in the 2015 earthquake but retrofitted within a year (Hanumandhoka Durbar Museum Development Committee, 2024, August)

monuments.name: Nasal Chowk
monuments.history: Nasal Chowk is the largest courtyard in the Hanuman Dhoka palace complex. It played a central role during the Malla period, serving as a space for various performances, including dances and theatrical acts. It was also a place where the king would meet with his subjects, and important matters concerning the palace were discussed. Additionally, during times of grief in the royal family, people would gather here to express their condolences. The chowk is named after the deity Nasal (Natyashwor), whose temple is located on the eastern side.

monuments.name: Mul Chowk
monuments.history: Mul Chowk holds great religious and ceremonial significance, as it was the site of coronations for Malla kings and major religious celebrations. It is closely linked with the Taleju Temple, located in the courtyard towards its north. Access to Mul Chowk was historically limited to the priests and their helpers, and even today, it is only open to the public once a year during the Navami celebration of Dashain. During Mohni or Dasain, the deity Taleju is brought down from the Taleju temple and resided in the south wing of Mulchowk. This chowk was not just the center of political power but also a focal point for the sacred rites of the palace.

monuments.name: Sundari Chowk
monuments.history: Sundari Chowk, located north of Mohan chowk was constructed by King Pratap Malla in 1651 AD, is known for its beautiful architecture and central golden water spout. This chowk also features the famous 7th century stone sculpture of Kaliyadaman, depicting Krishna subduing the serpent Kaliya. Apart from its aesthetic appeal, Sundari Chowk was used as a living quarter for the royal family, adding to its historical significance as a functional part of the palace.

monuments.name: Mohan Chowk
monuments.history: Mohan Chowk was the main residential quarter for the Malla kings. In addition to being the royal living space, it also hosted important meetings, including those with foreign dignitaries. This chowk was historically significant as the place where royal family members were sometimes punished. A major attraction of Mohan Chowk is the Panchmukhi Hanuman Temple, noted for its circular tiered roofs. This temple, built in 1655 AD, is closed to the public and is accessible only to priests for rituals.

monuments.name: Lohan Chowk
monuments.history: Lohan Chowk, built during the reign of King Prithvi Narayan Shah and his successors, is characterized by four corner towers. Each of these towers symbolizes a part of the Kathmandu Valley: Vidas Mandir (Lalitpur Tower), Lakshmi Vilas (Bhaktapur Tower), Bangla Mandir (Kritipur Tower), and Nautale Durbar (Basantapur Tower). These towers are a significant architectural feature, representing the unity of the valley under Shah rule.

monuments.name: Nhuchhen Chowk
monuments.history: Nhuchhen Chowk is historically notable as the place where King Prithvi Narayan Shah entered Hanuman Dhoka palace during Indra Jatra in 1768 AD, marking the end of Malla rule and the beginning of Shah dominance. The southern wing of this chowk was transformed into the Gaddi Baithak (Throne Room) by Prime Minister Chandra Shamsher in 1908 AD. This hall served as a ceremonial space where kings received foreign ambassadors, and its balcony is still used to view the annual Kumari chariot procession.

monuments.name: Lamo Chowk (Vayu Chowk)
monuments.history: Lamo Chowk, also known as Vayu Chowk, is a long rectangular courtyard located to the west of Nasal Chowk. It adjoins the Gaddi Baithak and contains an important historical feature—a lavatory built by King Pratap Malla, the first of its kind in Nepalese history.

monuments.name: Dakh Chowk
monuments.history: Dakh Chowk, located on the west side of Nasal Chowk and adjoining Lamo Chowk, was built by Jung Bahadur Rana for Prince Trailokya. Its construction signifies the expansion and modernization of the palace complex during the Rana period, highlighting the shifting power dynamics within the royal family.

monuments.name: Masan Chowk (Kanhel Chowk)
monuments.history: Masan Chowk, also known as Kanhel Chowk, is separated from Dakh Chowk by a wall and houses the Degu Tale and Bhagwati Temples. Historically, this area was a cremation ground known as Karnadeep when Indrachowk was the confluence of the Bagmati and Bishnumati rivers. Over time, with the expansion of Kathmandu, the cremation ground was moved. Masan Chowk was used for Navdurga Dance performances, which were believed to ward off evil spirits during the Malla reign.

monuments.name: Trishul Chowk
monuments.history: Trishul Chowk, located to the north of Taleju Temple, is named after a large stone trident (Trishul) located in the courtyard. This chowk is also home to an Agnishala (fire shrine) and a Dabali (performance platform). A stable for Taleju’s horse is located in this area, and around the chowk are notable stone icons, including Jalasayan Narayan, Garuda, and Vamsa Gopal. These elements make Trishul Chowk an integral part of the religious and cultural heritage of the Hanuman Dhoka complex.

monuments.name: Nag Pokhari
monuments.history: Nag Pokhari is located east of Dashain Ghar and features a pond with a serpent hood (Naga) atop a wooden column. This feature was relocated from Tagwo Pukhu in Bhaktapur by King Pratap Malla in 1663 AD. Around the pond, there are stone sculptures of elephants, Parvati, Shiva, and a Chaturvyuha Vishnu icon, showcasing the courtyard’s religious significance.

name: Pashupati
history:
The Pashupatinath Temple is one of the oldest and most revered Hindu shrines in the world. Located in the city of Kathmandu, Nepal, the temple complex is dedicated to Lord Shiva, one of the three primary deities of Hinduism. The temple's history spans thousands of years, and its evolution provides a fascinating glimpse into the development of Hinduism in the Indian subcontinent.Pashupatinath Temple is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the most important pilgrimage sites for Hindus around the world. The temple complex covers an area of around 264 hectares and includes over 500 shrines and monuments, including the main Pashupatinath temple, the Boudhanath Stupa, and the Guhyeshwari Temple. The temple attracts millions of visitors each year, who come to offer prayers and seek blessings from Lord Shiva.
The Pashupati Area, also known as Maheshorpur, Swarnapuri, Nepal Puri, and Gola, is a revered divine heritage site in Nepal. Centered around Lord Pashupatinath, it features nine gates, platforms, squares, ponds, grounds, Shakti Peeths, and territorial protectors, symbolizing a unified divine structure.

monuments.name: Pashupati Temple
monuments.history:
The origins of the Pashupatinath Temple date back to the ancient Kirat dynasty in Nepal. According to the Gopal Raj Vamshavali manuscript, a cowherd named Surya noticed that one of his cows, Kaili, produced no milk while grazing by the Bagmati River, unlike the others. Upon observing Kaili, he discovered that she would wander off alone, and milk would miraculously flow from her udder, soaking the ground. Surprised, Surya dug at the spot and uncovered a divine light, revealing a Shiva Linga, which is now enshrined at the temple.
The Bhasa Vamshavali traces the origin of Pashupati to the Dwapar Yuga, linking it to the Pandavas. Burdened by the curse of Gotra Hatya for killing their kin, the Pandavas sought Mahadev's blessing to absolve their sins, following Lord Krishna's advice. When Mahadev learned of their arrival, he transformed into a buffalo and hid among the herd. The Pandavas recognized him and attempted to gain his darshan, but Mahadev tried to disappear into the earth. As a result, his face appeared in Kathmandu, which became known as Pashupatinath.
According to the Nepal Mahatmya and Himvatkhanda, Lord Shiva once wandered from Kailash and arrived in Kathmandu, where he became enchanted by its beauty and transformed into a deer, living in bliss. The gods, concerned by his disappearance, searched for him and found the mystical deer grazing by the Bagmati River. Suspecting it was Shiva, they caught its horn. In a tug-of-war, the horn broke, and Shiva vanished, returning to Kailash. The broken horn was later enshrined as a Shiva idol, according to another legend. (Shrestha, 2023)
According to legend, Pashupatinath emerged during a conflict between Brahma and Vishnu, manifesting as a divine light that later took the form of Lord Pashupatinath with five faces: Tatpurush (East), Sadojat (West), Bamdev (North), Aghor (South), and Ishan (Above). Worshiped as a Shri Yantra, symbolizing cosmic energy, daily rituals also honor Tripurasundari and the divine union of Shiva and Parvati.
The site’s sacred layout includes nine Shakti Peeths arranged in a trident shape, with prominent temples like Vajreshwari, Vatsaleshwari, Guhyeshwari, Jaya Vagishwari, Mangaleswari, Vankali, Bhuvaneshwari, Rajarajeshwari and Nil Saraswati. Other significant temples include Jhamkeshwari, and Manmaneshwari. Together, these elements embody Nepal’s spiritual and cultural heritage, drawing devotees from across the world. (Bhandari K.M (2024, November 27). Insights on Pashupatinath Temple [Interview with the  priest of Pashupatinath].)

(Bhandari K.M (2024, November 27). Insights on Pashupatinath Temple [Interview with the  priest of Pashupatinath].)

monuments.name: Pingalamai Temple (Vajreshwari)
monuments.history: The shrine of Pingalamai, a protective goddess of Pashupati Area, is located beneath a bridge in Pode tola near Tilganga. Locally revered as Mahalaksmi, it features ancient statues, including Varahi, Kali, and Bhairava. An annual Desoddhara Puja (Annual worship honoring Pingalamai as a protective goddess. Rituals are conducted by representatives of Deopatan's four varṇas (brahman, Chhetri, Vaishya, and Shudra). Only residents of the specific Deopatan area can participate, and only once in their lifetime), preceded by the Duducyacya procession, involves tantric and Vedic rituals performed by Deopatan residents. Besides that Pingalamai Palanquin Procession is conducted which departs from Pingalamai shrine to the eastern gate of the Pashupatinath temple organized by two Dangol  from Bhakuna tole and Laganalachi tole in Deopatan. (Bhandari K.M (2024, November 27). Insights on Pashupatinath Temple [Interview with the  priest of Pashupatinath].)

monuments.name: Four Shivalaya
monuments.history: The four Shivalayas—Rana Mukteshwar, Bala Mukteshwar, Janga Mukteshwar, and Jagad Mukteshwar—constructed in 1888 AD by Prime Minister Bir Samsher in honor of janga Bahadur Rana, are located south of the Rajarajeshwari Temple. These dome roof temples, finished in white lime with ornate Chepu-adorned stone arches, house Shivalingas and statues of Vishnu, Surya, Ganesh, and Durga in their respective sanctums. Nearby, the Agnihotrashala, established in 1962 AD, hosts daily fire rituals and annual Shivaratri celebrations led by local Brahmin priests. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Rajarajeshwari Temple
monuments.history:
Rajarajeshwari Temple, located south of Pashupatinath by the Bagmati River, is one of the nine Shakti Pithas and a significant site of worship. Renovated in 1408 AD during the reign of Jaya Dharma and Jayajyoti Malla, it enshrines twelve clay deities, including Nava Durga, Bhairavas, and the five-faced Shiva lingam, Panchamukhi Mahadev. The eight-petalled stone mandala, symbolizing the Shri Yantra, represents its main deity, Rajarajeshwari.
According to local belief, Rajarajeshwari has an interesting origin story associated with Bhaktapur. It is said that she expressed a desire to leave Bhaktapur and explore the world beyond. However, the priest of the temple agreed to her request on the condition that she must return before sunrise. If she failed to do so, she would be bound to stay wherever she was at that moment. Unfortunately, Rajarajeshwari  was unable to make it back to Bhaktapur before sunrise. As a result, she had to remain in the Pashupati area.
The temple features intricate gilded details added by Jitajanga Rana in the 19th century. Rituals, including daily worship by Karmacharya priests and annual NavaDurga mask dances, connect the site to Bhaktapur’s traditions. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Jitajangaprakaseswar Temple
monuments.history: The Jitajangaprakaseswar Temple, built in 1874 AD by Jit Janga Rana, is a unique, dome-shaped structure within the Rajarajeshwari Temple complex. Notable for its oval design, it houses three main shiva lingas, with the central one dedicated to Jitajangaprakaseswar. The temple is adorned with ancient statues, including Nandi, Bhairava, and a trident, and is surrounded by shrines to deities like Krishna and Lakshmi. After being damaged in the 2015 earthquake, the temple was reconstructed in 2020 AD. Daily rituals and special ceremonies, including the Shivaratri festival, are held here, making it a vibrant spiritual site connected to the rich cultural heritage of the area.(NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Tarakunda
monuments.history: Tarakunda, located south of the Rajarajeshwari Temple, is a rectangular pond with a cemented bottom and a stone water spout shaped like a tiger’s head, channeling underground water into the pond. While not a major sacred Pond , it is part of the pilgrimage route in the Pashupati area where visitors perform ablutions and worship. Though lacking historical inscriptions or significant myths, Tarakunda holds cultural importance for pilgrims, guided by the tirtha guru, Nemuni (Nemuni is the title given to a Bhatta Bhramhin from the Shankaracharya Aagamghar in the Pashupati area, who acts as the tirtha guru (pilgrimage guide)).(NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Vankali
monuments.history: The Vanakali Temple, located southwest of Pashupati in a forested area, is dedicated to the goddess Vanakali, "Kali of the forest." The eight-armed statue, believed to date from the 9th to 12th centuries, depicts the goddess standing on a corpse, holding a sacrificial sword, a severed head, and a drum. Legend ties her to King Shivadevavarman and her role in protecting the area. Renovated by King Mahendra in 1958 A.D, the temple hosts a palanquin procession each year on the 3rd day of the bright Baishak fortnight and is associated with annual sheep sacrifices. The temple also receives special worship from the Pashupatinath Guthi Goshwara. (Bhandari K.M (2024, November 27). Insights on Vankali [Interview with the  priest of Pashupatinath].)

monuments.name: Vanavinayak Temple
monuments.history: Vanavinayak Temple, located east of Vanakali Hiti in the Pashupati Area, is a revered shrine dedicated to Ganesh, known locally as "Hyau Ganesh" or "Red Ganesh." Believed to have been established by Licchavi King Shivadeva Varmā, the temple features a south-facing brick structure with a metal-sheet roof and no doors at the sanctum entrance. Inside, a four-armed Ganesh statue is adorned with oil and vermillion. Though its exact construction date is unclear, the current statue dates back to the 15th-17th centuries. The temple, renovated in 2009, plays a central role in local religious ceremonies, with a special meal for children held annually on the 14th day of chaitra dark fortnight. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Panchadevala Temple
monuments.history: The Panchadevala Temple ensemble, built in 1870 AD, by King Surendra Vikrama Shah and his family, consists of five dome-style temples on a raised platform south of the Pashupatinath temple. The central Surendresvara Temple, with its gilded finial and stone arch, stands out among the four corner temples. The ensemble was funded by five donors, including King Surendra Vikrama Shah and his family, each contributing a bell to the temples. Damaged in the 2015 earthquakes, the ensemble includes shrines dedicated to various deities like Ganesh, Durga, and Vishnu. Daily rituals and annual ceremonies, such as the anniversary worship on Ashar 8, continue to be observed. (Bhandari K.M (2024, November 27). Insights on Vankali [Interview with the  priest of Pashupatinath].)

monuments.name: Bhuvaneshwari Temple
monuments.history: The Bhuvaneshwari Temple, located in the southwest corner of the Pashupatinath temple, is dedicated to the goddess Bhuvaneshwari, one of the nine deities in the region. Built in the traditional Nepali mandapa style with a two-tiered roof, it features intricate woodwork and brick mortar. While the temple was originally thatched, a zinc roof was added to protect it from monkeys. The temple is not home to an anthropomorphic idol but a symbolic instrument, worshiped by Karmacharyas. It is part of the cultural fabric of the area, with connections to the Sikali Jatra of Harisiddhi and Trishul  Yatra. Restoration efforts include those by Narendra Malla and the Nepalese army in the 20th century. Visitors can view the temple from outside the sanctum, as entry is restricted. (Karmacharya R (2024, November 22). Insights on Bhuvaneshwari temple [Interview with the  priest of Bhuvaneshwari Temple].)

monuments.name: Aruna Dhara
monuments.history: The Aruna Dhara, located east of the Bhuvaneshwari Temple, is a historic water spout dating back to the 12th-13th century, though it is currently non-functional. The site features a rare statue of Sūrya, the sun god, depicted riding a chariot driven by Aruṇa, accompanied by 12 deities and two attendants. The traditional spout, called a hiti, is set two feet below street level, with only its tip visible. While its connection to Licchavi King Narendradeva’s water spouts is uncertain, fragments of Licchavi chaityas found nearby add to the site's historical significance. The Aruna Dhara remains an important relic of ancient water management and art in the Pashupati Area. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Daksinamurti Temple
monuments.history: The Daksinamurti Temple, located near the western entrance of the Pashupati Area, is dedicated to Pashupatinath's guru and features a two-tiered copper roof with intricate carvings of Bhairava and the astamatrika goddesses. Inside, the black stone statue of Daksinamurti, seated under a Kalpabrikshya tree, is surrounded by statues of  22 sages (Rishis). Though the temple's construction date is unclear, it is believed to have been established in 1317 AD by King Rudra Malla to end droughts, with later renovations under King Nripendra Malla in the 17th century. Rituals are performed daily by the Rajopadhyaya priest, with special worship on guru purnima. The temple has undergone repairs following 2015 earthquake damage and continues to be a center of spiritual activity. The temple is open all day for visitors.  (Bhandari K.M (2024, November 27). Insights on Vankali [Interview with the  priest of Pashupatinath].)

monuments.name: Pacha Ganesh
monuments.history: The ancient Pacha Ganesh idol in Pachutol, dating back to the 5th–7th centuries, is an exceptional east-facing statue linked to Pashupatinath as his guardian son. Set in a shikhara-style temple with 21 finials, flanked by lions, it is surrounded by relics like Licchavi-era chaityas, a Panchamukhi (five-faced) Pashupatinath, and representations of Parvati (Guheshwori) and Mahadev. Integral to local rituals, devotees offer prayers here before weddings, bratabandha, or festivals like Vatsaleshwari Jatra, where deities are honored with parikrama (circumambulation).  (Bhandari K.M (2024, November 27). Insights on Vankali [Interview with the  priest of Pashupatinath].)

monuments.name: Varuna Dhara
monuments.history: The Varuna Dhara, located south of the Bhakuṃtvāḥ path in the Pashupati Area, is an ancient water spout with significant archaeological value, featuring an east-facing spout adorned with a statue of Varuna the water deity. The spout is set in a walled depression (hitigah) with carved yaksa figures and a stone tank collecting water. A stone statue of Umāmaheśvara is located in the northwestern corner. Built during the early Licchavi period, it has undergone renovations in 1914, 1989, and 2002, though it is no longer operational as of 2023. Locals believe that ritual baths in the nearby water holes, like Varuna Kunada, offer spiritual merit. The site is open to visitors and remains an important cultural and historical landmark in the area. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Nasatva Ganesh
monuments.history: The Nasatva Ganesh shrine, located north of the stone-paved path leading to the Aryaghat cremation grounds, was once the central shrine for the Nasatva neighborhood. This south-facing temple features a four-armed Ganesh, holding a bead garland, axe, protective gesture, and a bowl of sweets. The shrine is adorned with a carved Ganesh figure above the archway, and fragments of Shiva statues are placed beside the deity. Although many houses in the area were demolished for development, some local families continue to honor this Ganesh as their patron deity. The temple remains a significant cultural and spiritual site, with daily offerings and domestic rites still observed by the community. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Nasahdya
monuments.history: The Nasahdya shrine, located east of the Bhuvaneshwari temple, is dedicated to the deity of music, dance, and drama, traditionally represented by a triangular hole in the wall. This unique shrine not only features the triangular opening but also depicts Nasahdya in a dance pose with twelve arms, holding various tools. Alongside the central figure, sculptures of Vidyadhari, Ganesh, Umamaheshwar, Shiva, and Vishnu add to its significance. Once the hub of cultural activities, the area, known as Nasatva, was home to music and dance training. However, the demolition of nearby homes in 1998 displaced the community, leading to the cessation of these cultural practices. Dating back to the 9th-13th century, the shrine holds historical and artistic value, though its connection to the community has been weakened. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Pode Pati
monuments.history: The Pode Pati, also known as Pode Phalcha, is a historically significant structure located on the northern side of the main road leading to the Arya Ghat cremation ground. Once surrounded by traditional homes in the 'Kolachi  Tole  neighborhood, it is the only building remaining after the area’s redevelopment. The Phalcha, with an inscription from 1866 AD, and renovations in 1997 and 2008 AD, is tied to the local Pode community, who were once considered "untouchable." The Phalcha is historically significant for its role during the Pingamai chariot procession, where Pode community members would distribute samay baji and sing devotional songs. While these traditions have ended, the chariot procession still pauses in front of the Phalcha, preserving its cultural importance. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Drisheshwar, Ishworeshwar and Sireshwar
monuments.history: This temple was built in 1859 AD and located north of the Bhasmeshwar Shivalinga by the Bagmati River, features three Shivalayas within a single sanctum, each topped with a domed roof. The temple has three entrances dedicated to the deities Drihmeshwar, Ishworeshwar, and  Sireshwar, with stone arches depicting mythical water creatures and Bhairava masks. The site, once home to a Licchavi-era Shivalinga, also houses a 12th-13th century Umamaheshwar statue. Built by Dillishamsher Basnet, a high-ranking officer under Prime Minister Janga Bahadur Rana, the temple is associated with the Rana period and its social elite. Today, daily rituals are still performed by a Brahmin priest, with a trust established in 1868 AD for temple upkeep. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Bhasmeshwar Shivalinga
monuments.history: The Bhasmeshwar Shivaliṅga, established in 533 AD (590 BS) by Dhruvasaṅgha, is located at the Bhasmeshwar Ghat by the Bagmati River, south of Pashupatinath temple. This sacred site features five main Shiva Lingas, with Bhasmeshwar at the center, surrounded by Natheshwar, Sthiteshwar, Ravishwar, and Subheshwar, along with four smaller Shivaliṅgas. It is believed that the ashes from cremations at the Ghat, in contact with Bhasmeshwar Shivalinga, absolve sins and grant liberation. Ritual baths at the Aakashbhairav Tirtha during Mārgaśīrṣa’s (month in the Hindu lunar calendar. It is typically the ninth month and corresponds roughly to Nov-Dec in the Gregorian calendar) in which the new moon is said to fulfill desires. Worship here is thought to resolve ancestral and family disputes. Daily rituals are performed by the Bhatta priest from the Pashupatinath Aagamaghar, with the site linked to beliefs of liberation and ancestral healing. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Cremation Ghats
monuments.history: Arya Ghat, located at the foot of Pashupatinath Temple along the Bagmati River, is one of the holiest cremation grounds in the Kathmandu Valley. Comprising a series of paved platforms leading to the river, it is home to significant shrines, including Gangamai and Virupaksha, near the eastern stairway. In Hinduism, the Bagmati River near Pashupatinath Temple is considered like the sacred Vaitarani River. Crossing it symbolizes the soul’s journey to liberation after death. The river represents purification and the transition from the physical world to spiritual freedom. Cremation by the Bagmati is believed to cleanse sins and help the soul reach moksha (liberation).Cremation rituals, performed 24/7, follow Hindu traditions where the deceased’s elements—fire, water, air, earth, and sky—are returned to their respective realms. The procession, known as Malami, features rhythmic music or conch blowing, signaling the passing. This sacred site symbolizes the cycle of life, death, and rebirth, with its deep spiritual significance attracting both locals and visitors. (Jenkins et al., 2006)

monuments.name: Mangala Gauri Temple
monuments.history: The Mangala Gauri Temple, near Vatsala Temple within the Pashupatinath complex, honors Mangala Gauri, a protective goddess of Pashupatinath. Its sanctum enshrines a 7th-century stone image of the goddess in a lalitāsana pose, adorned with eight arms holding various objects. The square brick structure features copper-sheeted roofs but lacks a finial and door leaves, with ancient sculptures of guardian deities and Yamuna complementing the sanctum. Rituals led by Karmacharya priests include the annual ja payagu rite (Rice Drying Ritual) and Trishul  Jatra blending tradition and community participation. Renovated in 2017 by the Chaudhary Foundation, this temple connects with nearby sacred sites like Vatsala Temple and remains a testament to Kathmandu's cultural and spiritual heritage.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Vatsala Temple
monuments.history: The Vatsala Temple, located southeast of Pashupatinath Temple on the banks of the Bagmati River, is a historic shrine dedicated to Goddess Vatsaleshwari, one of the nine protective deities of Pashupatinath. The temple, known as the 'Aadi Mulapitha.The goddess is enshrined as a simple stone yantra. The Vatsala Temple  is steeped in legends. According to the Nepala-mahatmya , Goddess Vatsala was named by Lord Shiva, moved by Parbati  affection while he roamed as Pashupati in the Shleshmantaka jungle. The temple’s rituals include sacrifices, grand feasts, and the sacred bathing of the goddess with ‘Thwon’ (fermented beer), a tradition tied to local lore. It is managed by the Khadgi community, with rituals conducted by the Karmacharya priest of Jaya Vagishwari. The temple was renovated in 2017 by the Chaudhary Foundation and the Pashupati Area Development Trust. It is believed that Bathing in the Bagmati River and viewing Vatsala is believed to grant devotees a place in Kailash, Lord Shiva’s  divine abode.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Anantanarayan
monuments.history: The Anantanarayan statue, crafted in the 16th century during King Amara Malla's reign, is a masterpiece of 121 terracotta pieces, located north of the Vatsala Temple on the Bagmati River’s western bank. Depicting the deity with a discus, mace, lotus, and conch, sheltered by a seven-hooded serpent, it features intricate terracotta reliefs on its outer walls. According to legend, potters from Bhaktapur secretly installed the statue outside Pashupatinath Temple due to caste restrictions. The shrine plays a key role in the Bala Chaturdashi rituals, where families honor deceased relatives. Renovated by the Chaudhary Foundation in 2017, it is a significant cultural landmark linked to nearby sacred sites, such as Pashupatinath and Panca Ganesh, offering visitors a glimpse into Kathmandu’s spiritual and artistic heritage.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Lalitmukteswar temple
monuments.history: The Lalitamukteswar Temple, built in 1874 AD by Jitajanga Rana, stands south of Virupaksha Temple at Arya Ghat in Pashupati. This east-facing brick temple features a bell-shaped roof and a Chepu-adorned stone archway leading to a sanctum housing the Lalitamukteswar Shivalinga, surrounded by statues of Durga, Vishnu, Kamadev, and a Bhairav mask. Daily rituals are conducted by priests from the Agama Ghara and Gangamai Temple, with a Lamichhane Brahmin caretaker maintaining the site.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Virupaksha Temple
monuments.history: Located near Arya ghat in Pashupati, this stone temple with a bell-shaped roof houses the partially buried 4th-century AD statue of Virupaksha, believed to predate Hindu influence in Nepal. The statue, Discovered by a member of the Kirat community in 1965 AD, it is thought that the statue once held a Shivalinga in one hand and a rosary in the other., is three-eyed, with cascading hair, and is thought to represent Shiva, Kali, or a Naga leader. Local lore claims offering libations prevents the statue from rising and ending the Kali Yuga. The temple, likely built in the 19th or 20th century, also enshrines deities like Mṛgeśvara, Durga, and Ganesh. Daily rituals are conducted by priests of  Pashupatinath, but the eastern boundary wall of the Pashupatinath complex restricts circumambulation. Community efforts and religious practices ensure its preservation.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Gangamai temple
monuments.history: The Gangamai Temple, located near Virupaksha Temple at Arya Ghat within the Pashupati area, is a Rana-era stone temple featuring a domed roof adorned with a carved Sri Yantra and an entrance archway depicting Chepu, a mythical water creature. Inside, the marble statue of Goddess Ganga is flanked by Vedavyasa and Shiva-Parvati. Built before 1848 AD, the temple is associated with Prime Minister Janga Bahadur Rana’s wife, Gangadevi, though inscriptions suggest earlier origins. Daily worship is performed by a Paudela Brahmin, with the temple open for morning and evening rituals, including an Arati. The annual chariot procession on the 7th day of Ashar marks the start of monsoon, showcasing community devotion and the temple’s cultural significance.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Brahma Naal
monuments.history: Brahma Nal, located at the feet of Pashupatinath Temple, is a sacred site where the holy waters of the Bagmati River flow, believed to purify the soul and help the deceased attain liberation (Mukti) and reach Shiva Loka. The site is associated with a unique Hindu funeral ritual where the deceased is immersed in water to facilitate the escape of life energy, symbolizing the transition from the physical to the divine. It is also believed that the convergence of waters from the Bagmati River, Pashupati Jhal, and Guhyeshwari creates a powerful spiritual current called Triveni. Marked by a stone structure added to compensate for declining water levels, Brahma Nal remains an important spiritual site, closely linked to Pashupatinath and the cycle of life and rebirth.  (Baidhya S (2024, November 19).Insights on Brahma Naal [Interview with Chairman of Shree Pashupatinath Aryaghat Service Center].)

monuments.name: Fifteen Shivalayas
monuments.history: The Pandra Shivalaya, a group of 15 shrines dedicated to Shiva, is located east of the Bagmati River, opposite the Pashupati cremation grounds. These stone temples feature bell-shaped roofs with metal finials, square sanctums open on all sides, and intricately carved stone archways (to Ranas) adorned with the mythical Chepu. Community involvement ensures their upkeep, with rituals conducted by local priests. Visiting hours are flexible, making it accessible to devotees and tourists alike.

monuments.name: Ekadash Rudreshwar Temple
monuments.history: The Ekadash Rudreshwar Temple, located on the route from Aryaghat to Mrigasthali in the Pashupati area, is unique for housing 11 Shiva lingas on a single jalhari, symbolizing Shiva's 11 forms as described in ancient texts. This temple is constructed in hybrid structure blends Newari, Rajput, and Mughal architectural styles, featuring wooden doors and intricate carvings. Despite its historical and cultural significance, the temple remains in a deteriorated state after the 2015 earthquake, with cracks and water damage evident. Daily worship continues by Bhatta priests, but public access is restricted, and major rituals, including those for Shivaratri, have ceased. Conservation efforts are urgently needed to restore this architectural gem and preserve its rich heritage. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Vishnu Temple (Ramchandra Temple)
monuments.history: The Rāmacandra Temple, also known as the Rāmaparivāra Temple, is a stone temple located north of the Laxminarayan Temple near the Bhasmeshwar Ghat in the Pashupati area. Built in the early 20th century, it features a metal finial, stone arches adorned with Chepu figures, and an ambulatory path around the sanctum. Inside, a marble statue of Lord Rāma is accompanied by Sita, Laxman, Hanuman, and his sons Lava and Kusha. A bell gifted by Prime Minister Bhim Shamsher in 1931 AD hangs at the northern gate. Managed by Brahmin students from a nearby ashram, the temple hosts daily worship and a grand celebration for Ram Nawami. This serene monument, blending cultural and historical significance, invites visitors to explore its rich heritage. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Gorakhnath Temple
monuments.history: The Gorakhnath Temple, an iconic shikhara-style temple in Mirgasthali within the Pashupati area, enshrines the silver-covered paduka (feet) of Gorakhnath, a revered Nath yogi. Established by King Jayasthiti Malla in 1394 AD, the temple features intricately carved stone columns, a golden finial, and guardian deity niches representing Indra, Yama, Varuṇa, and Kubera. Daily rituals are conducted by Nath ascetics in Vedic and Tantric traditions, with special offerings on Sundays and Tuesdays. The temple is a hub for festivals like Goraksa Jayanti and Bala Chaturdashi and plays a key role in the annual Gosainkunda pilgrimage. Surrounding it are 15 Shivalayas, each showcasing remarkable craftsmanship. Unaffected by the 1934 AD earthquake, the temple has seen renovations, including contributions from royal and local patrons, reflecting its enduring cultural and spiritual significance. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Visvarupa Temple
monuments.history: The Visvarupa Temple, Nepal's largest dome-style temple, stands in Mirgasthali near Pashupati area, housing a grand metallic statue of Visvarupa symbolizing Vishnu's cosmic form. Originally commissioned by King Pratap Malla in 1657 AD and relocated by Janga Bahadur Rana in 1863 AD, the statue blends Hindu and Buddhist symbolism, revered as Heruka or Avalokiteshwar by different communities. The temple features Anglo-Indian and Newar architecture, with four corner shrines dedicated to deities like Radha-Krishna and Shiva-Parvati, a Shree Yantra, and a historic Bhairava stone nearby. Severely damaged in the 2015 earthquake, the temple is under reconstruction. Special worship occurs biweekly and during the Dipankha Yatra. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Ganesh Temple
monuments.history: This 19th-century Ganesha statue, located along the stone-paved path connecting Arya Ghat and Guhyeshwari Temple, is a sacred site for devotees seeking blessings. Standing three cubits tall within a marble shrine, the four-armed Ganesha is adorned with oil and vermillion powder, alongside a stone symbolizing his mount, the shrew. Likely installed during, potentially in the Rana era, the pathway was paved and renovated by Sardar Ramakrishna Kunwar in 1868 AD. Worshipped daily by the priest of the nearby Rana Mukteshwar Temple, the statue attracts growing devotion, with offerings made for fulfilled wishes. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Mrigasthali
monuments.history: Cross the footbridge to the eastern bank of the Bagmati River and enter Mrigasthali, a serene forest where Lord Shiva is believed to have lived as a deer, enchanted by its beauty. Dotted with numerous votive lingams, including the Pandra Shivalaya (Fifteen Abodes of Shiva), this site is a key pilgrimage destination for followers of the Nath tradition. Guru Gorakhnath is said to have meditated here in samadhi for 12 years. The forest holds mythological significance, especially during Bala Chaturdashi (Marga Krishna), when spreading grains is believed to honor ancestors and bring spiritual blessings. This sacred ritual is equivalent to donating gold, deepening the site's cultural and spiritual allure. (Pashupatinath A Guide to Sacred Journey, 2023)

monuments.name: Kailash Hill
monuments.history: Kailash Hill, once part of the Shleshmantaka jungle, is a sacred hill spanning over 100 ropanis near the Bagmati River, separated from the forest by a natural shift in the river's course. Known as Mini Mount Kailash or Shiva Dham, it houses 9 Shiva Lingas and a Jyotirlinga, including the prominent Parvateshwar Shiva Linga at its center. According to a legend, Lord Shiva rested here while visiting the Pashupati area from Mount Kailash. The site hosts the Bala Chaturdashi mela in Mangsir (Nov-Dec) and facilitates Hindu rituals like Bratabandha (a Hindu ceremony that marks a boy’s transition into manhood and Homa (fire ritual in Hinduism) throughout the year. A Radha Krishna Temple lies to the east, and the Bishwo Shanti Sangha, established in 2016 B.S (1959 A.D), adds to its cultural significance. Revered for its resemblance to Devpatan, Shiva Lingas are said to be found beneath its grounds. (Pashupatinath A Guide to Sacred Journey, 2023)

monuments.name: Guhyeshwari Temple
monuments.history: Guhyeshwari Temple, east of Pashupatinath by the Bagmati River, is a revered Shakti Peetha, According to legend, this place is believed to mark where Goddess Sati's body parts fell. Built in the 17th century by King Pratap Malla, it is dedicated to Goddess Guhyeshwari, a form of Taleju Bhawani and the Shah Kings' family deity. The temple features tiered architecture with golden serpents on the roof and enshrines a kalasha (water jar) symbolizing the goddess. Devotees often visit it before Pashupatinath, honoring Shakti before Shiva. Rich in Tantric significance, it draws pilgrims for its sacred Bhairav Kunda pool and connection to Hindu mythology. Rituals and festivals like Mahashira worship are integral, with conservation efforts ongoing to preserve its spiritual and cultural legacy. (Guhyeshwari Temple, Nepal - Info, Timings, Photos, History, n.d.)

monuments.name: Kirateshwar Mahadev Temple
monuments.history: Kirateshwar Mahadev Temple, located in Mirgasthali near Pashupatinath, enshrines a tilted Shivaliṅga linked to Lord Shiva's legendary guise as a Kirat (hunter) in the Shleshmantaka jungle. Recognized as one of Nepal's 64 major Shivalingas, it is revered for fulfilling wishes and absolving sins. The temple's courtyard houses smaller Shivalingas, a Nandi statue, and a Trishul. Religious texts and local legends connect it to Arjuna from the Mahabharat and the Kirat community.In the Mahabharat, Arjuna, seeking divine guidance to enhance his archery skills before the Kurukshetra War, meditated in the Shleshmantaka jungle. Lord Shiva, disguised as a Kirat (hunter), appeared to test him. They both shot arrows at a boar, and after a dispute over who shot first, Arjuna realized the Kirat was Shiva. Impressed by Arjuna's humility, Shiva granted him the Pāśupatāstra, a powerful weapon for the upcoming war. Rituals like Bala Chaturdashi and Shivaratri draw devotees, while conservation efforts by figures like Purnachandra Maharaja ensure its legacy. It remains a vital spiritual hub for worship and cultural events. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Jaya Rudreshwar Temple
monuments.history: Jayarudreshwar Temple, built in 1815 AD by state officer Jaiphala Adhikari, lies west of the Gaurighat bridge near Pashupatinath. Featuring a square sanctum with a bell-shaped roof, it enshrines a Shivaliṅga named Jayarudreśvara, surrounded by deities like Vishnu, Ganesh, Bhagavatī, and Sūrya, reflecting the Shivapāñcāyana tradition. A Nandi statue guards its western entrance, while a rest house and Kāmadeva statue enhance its cultural ambiance. Known for rituals on Bala Chaturdashi, Shivaratri, and Rishi Panchami, Adhikari's contributions include the Gaurighat bridge, pathways, and a 48-ropani land trust for rituals and upkeep. Annual Bala Chaturdashi, Shivaratri, and Rishi Panchami ceremonies are conducted by an Acharya priest, with descendants participating in worship. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Gaurighat Satah
monuments.history: Located northeast of the Pashupati Temple, Gaurighat is a historically significant area featuring temples, shrines, and rest-houses (satah), including the three-story Gaurighat Satah, linked to Vajraghara and known for hosting rituals. Named after the sacred Gaurishila stone by the Bagmati River, the site also includes the nearby Jayanta Kumeda Satah and a Hanuman Shrine. Its architecture reflects Rana-era influences, with a bell donated by Mukhyani (Chief Queen) Vishnubhakta Kumari in 1888 AD. Renovated in 2013 by the Pashupati Area Development Trust, it survived the 2015 earthquake and continues to serve as a hub for cultural and religious activities. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Hanuman Shrine
monuments.history: The ŚākSita Hanumān statue at Gaurighat, believed to have been established by King Ranajita Malla (1722–1769 AD), depicts Hanuman seated on his left knee, granting blessings and protection through Varada and Abhaya mudra. Covered with layers of oil and orange powder applied by devotees, it is sheltered by a tin roof installed in 2019 with local support. Nearby are Shivaliṅgas and statues of deities like Lakshminarashimha, Garuda Narayana, and Vasudeva Kamalaja reflecting intricate 18th–19th century craftsmanship. Managed by an Acharya priest supported by the Pashupati Area Development Trust, the shrine sees devotees on Tuesdays, Saturdays, and festivals like Shivaratri and Hanuman Jayanti. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Jayanta Kumedana satah
monuments.history: The riverside rest house (sataḥ) at  Gaurighat, overlooking the Bagmati River, is a key site for Shraddha rituals honoring ancestors. This two-story structure, credited to army officer Jayanta Kumedāna, features a gable roof and intricately carved latticed windows, adorned with images of mother goddesses. Built alongside the cremation ground (ghat) established in 1826 AD by Shivananda Vaidya, it underwent renovations in 1967 AD and now partly serves as a residence for an ascetic. Once a hub for Rishi Panchami ritual baths, its cultural practices have evolved. Visitors can admire its heritage and connection to Bagmati’s spiritual traditions. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Pacima Dhoka
monuments.history: The Pacima Dhoka also called Seto Dhoka, or "White Gate," near Siphala Tole, once served as a major western entrance to the Pashupati Area before the construction of the Ring Road. Originally featuring a traditional dhvākhā design with a decorative arch, it now consists of two large brick pillars topped by a metal arch added during renovations in 2018 AD. This gate holds cultural significance during the annual Vatsaleshwari procession, where the goddess pauses at the gate for a ritual involving a fly whisk from Pashupatinath, symbolizing reconciliation. Reconstructed by Kathmandu Municipality in 1996 AD, the gate connects to Pashupatinath and other nearby heritage sites, embodying both historical and ritualistic importance. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Tamreshwar Temple
monuments.history: The Tamreshwar Temple, built in 1677 AD by Madhyeju in Navali Tole, is a two-tiered copper-roofed temple dedicated to a unique four-faced copper Shivaliṅga, symbolizing Tāmreśvara Mahādeva. Adorned with carvings of Shiva, Bhairava, and other deities, the temple reflects the Shiva Pāñcāyana tradition, with murals and statues inside its sanctum. Restored in 1990, the temple survived the 2015 earthquake unscathed. It plays a vital role in local festivals like Shivaratri and Dashain, where key processions, including those of Vajreśvarī and Gangamai, circumambulate the shrine. Additionally, devotees following the Salinadi bhrata and major rituals at Pashupatinath, such as priest appointments, include visits to this temple. Managed by the Sangata family and supported by local trusts, the site remains a hub of cultural and religious activity.  (Sangat S.k (2024, September 7). Insights on Tamreshwar Mandir [Interview with local culture expert].)

monuments.name: Tole Ganesh Temple
monuments.history: The two-tiered Ganesh Temple in Navali Tole, Deopatan, features a gilded finial, simple struts, and an ornamental arch with a standing Ganesh figure at the entrance. Inside, a four-armed Ganesh statue seated in a princely pose serves as the main deity, complemented by a Vishnu statue on the eastern wall. Expanded in 1827 AD during King Rajendra Vikrama Shah's reign and renovated in 2000 AD by the Pashupati Area Development Trust, the temple is central to local rituals, with a woman from the Maharjan caste maintaining daily worship. Known as the Sthan ganesh of Navali Tole, it is visited before life events and rituals, with its annual ceremony held in Chaitra. A nearby stone ball inside the temple, Bhimasenako Gucca, is believed to bless those who lift it with a son, adding to the temple’s cultural lore.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Mrityunjaya Mahadev
monuments.history: The Mrityunjaya Temple in Deopatan, Jaya Bageshwari, is a small yet spiritually significant temple dedicated to Lord Mrityunjaya, a form of Shiva believed to protect devotees from untimely death and offer liberation from life’s fears. This east-facing brick temple features a bell-shaped roof, a metal finial, and a sanctum housing a raised Shivaliṅga, with niches of other deities and a sacred Nandi statue outside. Known as the only Mrityunjaya Temple in Nepal, it draws devotees, particularly during Shivaratri, Indra Jātrā, and Śrāvaṇa Mondays. Although its origin is undocumented, the temple was rebuilt post-2015 earthquakes with local support. Managed by the community without a priest, the temple serves as a prayer site for health and peaceful transitions in life, emphasizing its cultural and spiritual value.(Sangat S.k ( 2024, September 7). Insights on Mrityunjaya Mahadev [Interview with local culture expert].)

monuments.name: Indreshwar Mahadev
monuments.history: The Indreśhwar Mahādeva Temple, west of Jaya Vagishwari Temple in Deopatan, is centered around a worn four-faced (caturmukhī) Shivaliṅga on high brick plinths, accessed by narrow stone steps. Though the original structure is lost, the plinths and steps hint at a grander medieval temple, with statues of Vishnu, Lakṣmī, and Umāmaheśvara nearby. The Pashupati Area Development Trust plans to reconstruct the temple, which was last renovated in 1996 AD. Managed by a local Kapālī family, the site hosts rituals and community bonfires during Shivaratri and remains a sacred destination during Dasaĩ, Tihāra, and other festivals.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Trishul Satah
monuments.history: The Trishul  Sataḥ, located in Jayavāgeśvarī Tole, plays a pivotal role in the annual Trishul Jatra (trident festival), celebrated on the 8th of the dark fortnight of Āṣāḍha. The structure, rebuilt by the Nepal Army in 1996 AD, houses chariots used during the festival. With simple lattice windows, an iron-sheet roof, and open sides, the building has four ground-floor bays and upper-floor living spaces. Local legends link the festival to a myth of a demon who kidnapped children, with tantric rituals and tridents used to deter such demons. The site is key to local traditions and an important stop during the festival. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Jaladya Satah
monuments.history: Jaladyaḥ Sataḥ, located northwest of the Jaya Vagishwari Temple, is a unique arcaded rest house and performance venue for the NavaDurga dancers from Bhaktapur and the mask dancers from Harisiddhi. This two-story structure, with a corrugated metal roof and intricately carved wooden columns, serves as a resting place for these ritual groups during performances in the Pashupati Area. Though lacking a deity statue, it has become a hub for local cultural activities, managed by the Jayabāgeśvarī Yūvā Klaba since 2007 AD. The building was reconstructed by the Pashupati Area Development Trust in 2002 AD and continues to serve the community with social initiatives like blood donation drives and health camps. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Lu Hiti
monuments.history: Lũ Hiti, or the "golden spout," northwest of Jaya Vagishwari Temple in Deopatan, is a historic Licchavi-era water spout, renowned for its gilded cover and two flanking shikhara-style temples dedicated to Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa and Dhanvantarī. Restored in 1387 AD by King Jayasthiti Malla, it channels water for temple rituals and features artifacts like a 13th-century Sūrya statue. Local legend links the spout to Lake Manasarovar, fulfilling Goddess Jaya Vagishwari’s divine wish. Unique for housing Nepal's only Dhanvantarī idol, the site reflects deep cultural significance. Despite renovations, including one in 2020 CE, the water flow has ceased, with alternative sources now used. Accessible year-round, it remains a vital link to Nepal’s sacred heritage.(Baidhya  M.R (2024, October 7). Insights on Luhiti [Interview with a local culture expert].)

monuments.name: Sridhar Vishnudevala
monuments.history: The Śrīdhara Vishnu Shrine, a small brick dome-shaped structure north of Lu Hiti, houses a medieval statue of Sridhar Vishnu with his consort Laxmi and mount Garuda. A Shivalinga, installed by the Vaidya family in 2003 CE, stands in front of the shrine, and a nearby jvālāvalī chaitya dates back to 1831 AD. Originally a private family shrine, it remains under the care of the Vaidya family, who perform daily rituals, annual worship during the full moon of Vaiśākha, and regular maintenance. Though modest, this shrine reflects a rich legacy of family devotion and architectural harmony.(NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Surya Temple
monuments.history: The Surya Temple, west of Jaya Vagishwari Temple and south of Lu Hiti, is a unique stone temple designed as a chariot pulled by horses, dedicated to Suryanarayan, the sun deity. Built around 1604 AD, the shikhara-style temple features intricate carvings of goddesses, an ornate arch, lion statues, and five stone horses on its northern plinth. After the theft of the original statue, a new one was installed, with worship now conducted by the priest of Jaya Vagishwari Temple. Nearby shrines include a four-faced Shivaliṅga and an empty Caturvyuha Narayana shrine. This temple showcases historical artistry and remains integral to local rituals and cultural preservation.(NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Jaya Vagishwari Temple
monuments.history: The Jaya Vagishwari Temple, located in Deopatan near Pashupatinath, is a revered shrine dedicated to the goddess Jaya Vagishwari, one of nine deities protecting Pashupatinath. This three-tiered medieval temple features ornate struts and (arch) adorned with Mahakali, Mahalaxmi, and Mahasaraswati. Rich in legends, it is believed the goddess aided Devapattan during an invasion and traveled from Tibet’s Mansarovar to heal locals. Unique traditions, such as the Mahadev-Parvati dance and Nava Durga rituals, highlight its cultural vitality. Sacred ceremonies like the annual Baisakh Purnima Puja and drought-invoking rituals at the Homa Kunda further enrich its spiritual significance. Recent renovations post-2015 earthquake preserved ancient elements, ensuring its legacy endures. Nearby attractions include Lu Hiti and Pashupatinath Temple. Visitors are welcome during daylight hours. .(Vaidya  M.R (2024, October). Insights on Jaya Vagishwari Temple [Interview with a local culture expert].)

monuments.name: Matsyendra Ganesh Temple
monuments.history: The Matsyendra Ganesh Temple, located east of Jaya Vagishwari Temple in Patan, is a historic two-tiered temple believed to predate the Bunga dyah chariot festival. Initially housed in a Phalcha (shelter), the deity MatsyendraGanesh was later enshrined in this west-facing temple with intricate struts depicting Ashta Matrika deities and an oblong banner hanging from its gilded finial. The four-armed Ganesh statue, seated in lalitāsana, holds a garland, radish, axe, and sweetmeats, flanked by Bala Ganesh and disciples. Local legend ties this Ganesh to rituals preceding the Bunga dyah festival, with holy water from the temple used for the deity’s ceremonial bathing. Reconstructed in 2011, the temple's daily rituals, including the Panch Bali sacrifice, are maintained by local residents and supported by the Guthi Sansthan. This serene site offers a glimpse into ancient traditions and its connection to nearby sacred sites like Jaya Vagishwari.(Baidhya  M.R (2024, September 7). Insights on Matsyendra ganesh temple [Interview with a local culture expert].)

monuments.name: Vaidya Phalcha
monuments.history: The Dathu Tole Phalcha, located east of the Jaya Vagishwari temple in Jaya Bageshwori, holds historical significance as a central gathering spot for the settlement. Built by the Vaidya community and later reconstructed in 1992 AD by the Pashupatinath Development Trust, the south-facing Phalcha is flanked by the Matsyendra Ganesh Temple and Napit Phalcha, symbolizing diverse community contributions. Once larger in size, road widening reduced its dimensions. Today, it houses the Jaya Vagishwari Tole Sudhar Samiti office, ensuring its upkeep. While it no longer hosts social or cultural events, its connection to nearby sacred sites and past traditions makes it a noteworthy landmark. (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Laliteshwar Temple
monuments.history: The Laliteshwar Temple, built in the 18th or 19th century, enshrines a unique four-faced Shivalinga as Laliteshwar, symbolizing Lord Shiva. Located east of Jaya Vagishwari Temple near the Ring Road, the west-facing temple features a bell-shaped roof, intricately carved statues of Uma Mahesvara, and a sacred Nandi pillar. Nearby, the historic Tri-Bhima Dhara water tap, installed in 1931 AD, and a Jahdhum tank enhance its cultural significance. Renovated by the Pashupati Area Development Trust in 2002, the temple fosters community involvement, with a local resident maintaining rituals and women offering prayers on Shrawan Mondays.  (NHDP, n.d.)

monuments.name: Balkumari Temple
monuments.history:
The Balkumari Temple, dating back to 1682 AD, is a charming west-facing temple in Deopatan, lending its name to Balkumari Tole. This small but sacred site houses Balkumari seated on a peacock, alongside statues of an 18-armed Durga and Ganesh, all adorned with intricate carvings and a stone to Rana. Local lore tells of Balkumari being bound to prevent her from leaving the temple, emphasizing her importance to the community. Maintained daily by residents, the temple features prominently in the annual Vatsaleshwari procession. Conveniently located near Jaya Vagishwari Temple, it offers a peek into the area’s vibrant religious history and local traditions.
At Balkumari Mandir, there has been a tradition from ancient times where beautiful children come out to perform dances. They also walk around (parikrama) the Pashupatinath temple, and this still happens today. Near the temple, there is a structure called "Ittapakha," which is located above it. From there, one can see Pashupatinath, and it aligns perfectly with Ishankunth. (Bhandari K.M (2024, November 27). Insights on Balkumari Temple[Interview with the  priest of Pashupatinath].)

name: Bouddha
history:
Boudha Stupa, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, stands as a blend of Newar, Tamang, Sherpa, and Tibetan cultures, making it a unique symbol of the rich cultural and spiritual diversity of the Kathmandu Valley. Located in the northeastern part of Kathmandu, this massive stupa is one of the largest in the world and serves as a major pilgrimage site for Buddhists from different traditions. The stupa's grand dome, adorned with the Buddha's all-seeing eyes, reflects the region's deep Buddhist heritage. Surrounding the stupa are numerous monasteries, shrines, and shops, creating a lively atmosphere where local traditions and rituals thrive. The area is especially significant during major Buddhist festivals like Buddha Jayanti and the Boudha Stupa Jatra, when devotees from diverse communities come together to celebrate and perform rituals. The cultural richness of Boudha makes it not only a religious hub but also a cultural crossroads, offering visitors a glimpse into the harmonious blending of various Buddhist traditions.
History
Boudha Stupa is one of the largest and most significant Buddhist sites in Nepal. Its origin remains unclear, with various historical sources offering different accounts. According to Nepalese records, the stupa was constructed during the Licchavi period. Gopal Raj Vansavali, a historical chronicle, credits King Shiva Dev with the construction of the stupa, while Mary Slusser suggests that King Mandeva may have been involved in its initial erection, with Shiva Dev later renovating it. Tibetan sources associate Boudha with King Songtsen Gampo, who is believed to have initiated the establishment of Buddhist temples, including the one at Boudha. After the Chinese occupation of Tibet in 1959, Boudha became a key center for Tibetan exiles, significantly contributing to its religious and cultural development.

Legends of Boudha Stupa
1. Kathmandu Legend: A prominent legend associated with the Boudha Stupa originates from Kathmandu during the Licchavi period. According to the story, King Dharmadev constructed a stone spout near his palace, but it mysteriously dried up, causing a severe drought in the kingdom. Distressed, the king consulted astrologers, who advised him to perform a human sacrifice to bring an end to the drought. They instructed the king to sacrifice someone who possessed all thirty-two virtues, a rare attribute. After an extensive search, it was discovered that only the king and his son, Manadeva, possessed these virtues.
Reluctant to sacrifice his son, the king decided to offer his own life and instructed Manadeva to decapitate a hooded stranger at the stone spout the next morning. However, when Manadeva returned to the palace, he realized, to his horror, that he had unwittingly killed his father. Filled with grief and guilt, Manadeva renounced the throne and chose to live a life of seclusion.
As time passed, the kingdom continued to suffer from the drought. In his despair, Manadeva had a vision in which Vajra Yogini appeared to him, instructing him to release a bird and build a stupa at the spot where the bird landed. Following this vision, Manadeva released a bird, and it landed at the site of what would become the Boudha Stupa. The construction of the stupa was difficult due to a lack of water to mix the clay. However, the laborers ingeniously collected dew using large sheets of cloth, which allowed them to complete the stupa. The use of dew, known as "khasu ti" in Nepal Bhasa, led to the stupa being named Khasu Ti Chaitya, a name that later evolved into Khasti Chaitya.
2. Tibetan Legend: A different, yet equally significant, legend comes from Tibetan Buddhism. According to this account, Avalokitesvara, the Bodhisattva of Compassion, had vowed to release all sentient beings from suffering. After years of efforts, Avalokitesvara looked down from his palace, only to find that many beings continued to suffer, despite his best efforts. Overcome by despair, Avalokitesvara wept, and his tears fell to the ground. These teardrops were believed to have transformed into the daughters of Indra, the king of the gods.
One of these daughters, Apurna, was born as a human named Jadzima, into a humble family. As she grew up, Jadzima worked hard to support her children and eventually saved enough money to fulfill a noble aspiration—to build a grand stupa that would help alleviate suffering. Despite opposition from the local nobility, who were jealous of her plans, the king granted her permission to build the stupa. The stupa came to be known as "Jharung Khasor," meaning "permission to build," symbolizing the king’s approval despite the resistance from the powerful elites. This stupa, built with the intention to end suffering, continues to serve as a significant religious and cultural landmark.

monuments.name: Ajima Temple
monuments.history: The Ajima Temple, located near Boudha Stupa, is a small, single-room structure with a copper roof and ceramic walls, featuring a steel lattice screen at its entrance. Inside, it holds a silver deity, often covered with cloth, depicted sitting with a human corpse on her lap. Above her, she is shown in a fierce pose, holding the same corpse. This deity, known by different names across communities, is seen as a protective goddess. In Tibetan Buddhism, she is referred to as Jadzima, while Newars call her Ajima, meaning "Grandmother." Hindus may associate her with deities like Sitala or Chamunda, fierce figures often depicted consuming corpses. Though considered wrathful, Ajima is seen as a protector, granting power to her devotees. The temple's origins and interpretations vary, with some connecting her to Hariti, a demoness who later became a protector of Buddha's shrines.

monuments.name: Ghyoi Lisang Pond (Peace Park)
monuments.history: Ghyoilisang Pond, now known as Peace Park, is located northwest of Boudha Stupa and covers an area of 15,289.80 sq. ft. Historically, it is believed that soil from the Boudha Stupa construction site was removed, gradually forming the pond. In recent years, the site has been transformed into Peace Park, a place of spiritual and cultural significance. In 2073 B.S., a statue of Guru Rinpochhe was placed at the center of the pond, and additional monuments, including chaityas and deity statues, have been added. The Peace Park now offers a tranquil space blending natural beauty with spiritual heritage.

monuments.name: Jamchen Monastery
monuments.history: Jamchen Monastery, located in the Boudha Stupa area, is the first monastery encountered when circling the stupa from the main gate. It belongs to the Sakyapa school of Himalayan Buddhism and is also known as Mustang Monastery, as it was funded by the Raja (King) of Mustang. The monastery was constructed starting in 1982 on land donated by the niece of the late Chini Lama. A three-story statue of Jampa (Maitreya or Future Buddha) is housed inside. The monastery's grand inauguration in 1986 was attended by former King Birendra of Nepal and unexpectedly honored by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter. According to some sources, it was founded by Venerable Chyopge Thichen Rinpoche and enshrines a statue of Trik Ma Buddha  (Gyalwa Jampa).

monuments.name: Guru Lhakhang Monastery
monuments.history: The Guru Lhakhang Monastery is a significant spiritual site of the Nyingma tradition. Located to the north of the stupa, this monastery, also referred to by locals as the "Tamang Gumba", is the oldest in the area adhering to the Nyingma and Jhyang Ter traditions. Within its sacred space are enshrined revered statues of Amitabha Buddha, Arya Avalokiteshvara, Guru Padmasambhava, and other prominent figures of Himalayan Buddhism. Visitors to the monastery can enjoy a breathtaking view of the majestic Boudha Stupa from its rooftop, adding to the monastery's spiritual and visual appeal.

monuments.name: Kyidong Tashi Samteling Monastery
monuments.history: Kyidong Tashi Samtenling Monastery, located near Boudha Stupa in Kathmandu, is the first Tibetan monastery established in the area after the Tibetan upheaval of 1960. It serves as a spiritual center, dedicated to preserving Tibetan traditions, rituals, and teachings. The monastery focuses on the tantric practices of the Geluk tradition, emphasizing rituals related to the three main tantric deities. It is known for its preservation of monastic arts, including ritual decoration, chanting, religious music, and tantric ceremonies. The monastery also provides modern education for its younger monks, offering courses in moral education and languages. It currently houses hundreds of monks, many from Tibet and Nepal’s remote regions like Rasuwa, Manang, and areas with Sherpa and Tamang communities.

monuments.name: Dilyak Yevam (1000 Buddha's Monastery) (Palri Tashi Migyur Dorje Gyaltsen Ling)
monuments.history: Located to the north-east of the Boudha Stupa, on the way to Phulbari, Dilyak Yevam Monastery, also known as Dhapsang Monastery, was founded by Venerable Rinpoche Dazang Ngeden Chhoeki Ngima Palsangpo in 1966 A.D. It follows the Kagyu tradition of Himalayan Buddhism and is renowned for housing statues of a thousand Buddhas. Regular Dharma rituals are performed daily, ensuring the continuation of spiritual practices for the community.

monuments.name: Thrangu monastery
monuments.history:
Thrangu Tashi Choling Monastery, located near the Great Stupa of Boudha, was founded by Thrangu Rinpoche in 1979. Initially envisioned as a library and later a shedra (Buddhist educational institute), the monastery gradually expanded to accommodate the growing number of monks. Today, it is home to approximately 80 monks, including staff and young monks aged 7-18 who receive both secular education and training in Buddhist rituals and philosophies.
The monastery holds special prayers on auspicious dates according to the Tibetan lunar calendar and fulfills prayer requests within the monastery or at devotees’ homes. Its monks later advance to higher Buddhist studies at the Vajra Vidya Institute Shedra or engage in the intensive year-long "Ngondro" preliminary practice at Namo Buddha. Thrangu Tashi Choling serves as a vital center for spiritual training and community rituals, reflecting its deep connection to the Buddhist heritage of the region.

name: Swoyambhu Mahachaitya
history:
The Swoyambhu Stupa is situated to the northwest of Kathmandu, atop a green hill known by various names: 'Gau Puche Parbat', 'Padmagiri' and 'Vajrakutta Parbat'. Nearby is Manjushree Hill, also referred to as 'Gau Singhe Parbat'. These hills are named 'Gau Singhe' and 'Gau Puche' because, from Nagarjun Hill, their shapes resemble a cow. Manjushree Hill appears as a cow's horn, while Swoyambhu Hill resembles the cow's tail.
The Swoyambhu Stupa, estimated to be over 1,500 years old, is a highly revered landmark in the Kathmandu Valley. The term 'Swoyambhu' in Nepal Bhasa translates to 'self-sprung' or 'self-manifested'. The most common route to the summit involves climbing 365 steps from the front entrance. Alternatively, the rear entrance, accessible by car or scooter, requires only a few steps to reach the top. The site’s integration of Hindu and Buddhist elements creates a distinctive and harmonious fusion of traditions that is seldom encountered elsewhere. (Buddhacharya, A. M. (2024, June 13). Insights on Swoyambhu Stupa [Interview with a local cultural expert].)
● Mythology of Swoyambhu
According to the Swoyambhu Purana, the Kathmandu Valley was once a vast and beautiful lake. When Vipaswi Buddha arrived, he planted a lotus seed at the site where the Swoyambhu Stupa now stands. The seed grew into a magnificent lotus with a thousand petals, its radiant light was visible from afar and drawing many pilgrims. Due to its luminous quality, the site came to be known as Jyoti Chaitya or Ratna Chaitya.
Impressed by the divine light of the lotus, Manjushri believed that draining the lake would make the site more accessible to human pilgrims. Using his great sword, he carved a gorge in the surrounding mountains, allowing the water to drain and revealing the valley that is now Kathmandu. As the lake dried up, the lotus emerged on the hill, which eventually became the location of the Swoyambhu Stupa.
Many years later, Shantikaracharya, who came to Nepal on pilgrimage, recognized the need to preserve this sacred light. To honor and protect the spot where the lotus had once bloomed, he is believed to have constructed the stupa. (Buddhacharya, A. M. (2024, June 13). Insights on Swoyambhu Stupa [Interview with a local cultural expert].)
● History of Swoyambhu
According to the Gopal Raj Vamsavali, a 14th-century manuscript from Nepal, the Swoyambhu Stupa was established by King Vrsadeva, the great-grandfather of King Manadeva (464–505 CE), during the Licchavi period in the early 5th century CE. This is supported by a damaged stone inscription at the site, which records that King Manadeva commissioned further work in 640 CE. Additionally, Emperor Ashoka is believed to have visited the site in the 3rd century BCE and constructed an early temple, which subsequently fell into disrepair for reasons that remain unknown. In 1349, during the first Muslim invasion of Kathmandu, the Swoyambhu Stupa was completely destroyed. It was subsequently repaired. Following the construction of the main stupa, additional monuments were added over time by various dynasties. The eastern stairway was built in the 17th century by King Pratap Malla, a prominent ruler of Kathmandu. (Vredeveld, n.d.)
In 1918 CE, with authorization from the Nepalese government, the 14th major renovation of Sri Swoyambhu Mahachaitya was undertaken. This restoration involved replacing the harmika and repairing the 13 bronze disks. The work was completed over a period of three years, finishing in 1921 CE. (Tuladhar, 2021)
The 15th renovation of Sri Swoyambhu MahaChaitya occurred between 2008 and 2010, resembling a massive jigsaw puzzle. Over 30,000 pieces were carefully removed, repaired, cleaned, and reassembled using more than 100,000 nails. Additionally, all the metal plates received a fresh layer of gold, utilizing 20 kg of the precious metal is one of the largest gold restoration projects ever undertaken. (Parashar, 2010)

● Buddhacharya Family
The Buddhacharya family descends from four legendary brothers tasked with preserving the traditions, norms, and values of Swoyambhu, as designated by Shantikar Acharya. The community is divided into four lineages—referred to as "KA: WA:"—which trace their roots back to these brothers, who established the clan centuries ago. Together, these lineages encompass 30 families, each representing the legacy of one of the four brothers. Each group has its own leader, guiding their members in honoring their shared heritage. (Buddhacharya et al., 2019)

monuments.name: Amitabha Buddha
monuments.history: Amitabha Buddha, one of the Five Dhyani Buddhas, represents the cosmic element of fire and is situated facing west within the stupa. Depicted in red, Amitabha embodies the purified form of desire and is commonly symbolized by a peacock. The peacock, which consumes poisonous plants yet reveals a vibrant and radiant tail, represents Amitabha Buddha’s power to alleviate suffering and transform negativity into enlightenment.

monuments.name: Ratnasambhava Buddha
monuments.history: Ratna Sambhava Buddha, one of the Five Dhyani Buddhas, represents the cosmic element of earth and is situated on the southern side of the stupa. Depicted in yellow, he performs the Varada Mudra with his right hand, symbolizing the granting of wishes, while holding a Cintamani jewel in his left hand, which rests on his lap. Seated on a horse throne, Ratna Sambhava Buddha embodies dynamic energy and the capacity to assist beings with great vigor, representing the purified form of pride.

monuments.name: Amoghasiddhi Buddha
monuments.history: Amoghasiddhi Buddha, one of the Five Dhyani Buddhas, represents the cosmic element of air and is depicted in green, facing north within the stupa. He is symbolized by the Garuda, which signifies his ability to perceive and transcend delusions from a distance. Performing the Abhaya Mudra, Amoghasiddhi Buddha embodies fearlessness. He is also depicted with a canopy of snakes above his head.

monuments.name: Aksobhya Buddha
monuments.history: Akshobhya Buddha, one of the Five Buddhas, represents the cosmic element of water and is positioned on the eastern side of the stupa.
